At a time when the American Indo-logical establishment regarded native Indian scholars merely as sources of information about language and texts, like the raw fiber that were taken from India to be processed in British mills, but seldom as scholars who might have their own ideas about how to process those texts, Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Long before it was politically respectable, let alone politically correct, to study the works of women or of ‘illiterate’ peasants, Raman valued their poetry, their stories and their counter-systems. At a time when Indian literature meant Sanskrit, and Sanskrit meant Greek and Latin, Raman arrived in Chicago to join Edward C. Dimock and the other ‘founding fathers’ in proclaiming to the world the relevance of Tamil and Bengali and the other mother tongues. Without so much as raising his gentle voice, he blazed a great path through the centre of Indological studies. He gave us so many new paradigms that no Indologist can now think about India without thinking through his thoughts.Who is A.K. Ramanujan compared to in the text?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.Chomsky
  • B.Sigmund Freud
  • C.Brunvand
  • D.British Mill Owners
Correct Answer: Sigmund Freud

From the passage:

 

"A. K. Ramanujan was one of those thinkers, like Freud (whom he greatly, though not uncritically, admired), who so transform our way of looking at a subject..."

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 47
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A. K. Ramanujan was one of those thinkers, like Freud (whom he greatly, though not uncritically, admired), who so transform our way of looking at a subject that we are in danger of undervaluing their contribution, since we have come to take for granted precisely what they taught us, as we view the subject through their eyes. At a time when the American Indo-logical establishment regarded native Indian scholars merely as sources of information about language and texts, like the raw fiber that were taken from India to be processed in British mills, but seldom as scholars who might have their own ideas about how to process those texts, Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Long before it was politically respectable, let alone politically correct, to study the works of women or of ‘illiterate’ peasants, Raman valued their poetry, their stories and their counter-systems. At a time when Indian literature meant Sanskrit, and Sanskrit meant Greek and Latin, Raman arrived in Chicago to join Edward C. Dimock and the other ‘founding fathers’ in proclaiming to the world the relevance of Tamil and Bengali and the other mother tongues. Without so much as raising his gentle voice, he blazed a great path through the centre of Indological studies. He gave us so many new paradigms that no Indologist can now think about India without thinking through his thoughts.What did Ramanujan teach in America?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.Process raw fibers in British mills
  • B.Weave theories, folktales, poems and books
  • C.Only Sanskrit literature
  • D.Only English Literature
Correct Answer: Weave theories, folktales, poems and books

From the passage:

“Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book”.

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 48
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A. K. Ramanujan was one of those thinkers, like Freud (whom he greatly, though not uncritically, admired), who so transform our way of looking at a subject that we are in danger of undervaluing their contribution, since we have come to take for granted precisely what they taught us, as we view the subject through their eyes. At a time when the American Indo-logical establishment regarded native Indian scholars merely as sources of information about language and texts, like the raw fiber that were taken from India to be processed in British mills, but seldom as scholars who might have their own ideas about how to process those texts, Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Long before it was politically respectable, let alone politically correct, to study the works of women or of ‘illiterate’ peasants, Raman valued their poetry, their stories and their counter-systems. At a time when Indian literature meant Sanskrit, and Sanskrit meant Greek and Latin, Raman arrived in Chicago to join Edward C. Dimock and the other ‘founding fathers’ in proclaiming to the world the relevance of Tamil and Bengali and the other mother tongues. Without so much as raising his gentle voice, he blazed a great path through the centre of Indological studies. He gave us so many new paradigms that no Indologist can now think about India without thinking through his thoughts.The languages that Ramanujan tried to bring to limelight in Indological studies is(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Morning)
  • A.Greek and Latin
  • B.Only Sanskrit
  • C.Tamil, Bengali and other mother tongues
  • D.French and German
Correct Answer: Tamil, Bengali and other mother tongues

“At a time when Indian literature meant Sanskrit, and Sanskrit meant Greek and Latin, Raman arrived in Chicago to join Edward C. Dimock and the other ‘founding fathers’ in proclaiming to the world the relevance of Tamil and Bengali and the other mother tongues”.

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Question 49
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A. K. Ramanujan was one of those thinkers, like Freud (whom he greatly, though not uncritically, admired), who so transform our way of looking at a subject that we are in danger of undervaluing their contribution, since we have come to take for granted precisely what they taught us, as we view the subject through their eyes. At a time when the American Indo-logical establishment regarded native Indian scholars merely as sources of information about language and texts, like the raw fiber that were taken from India to be processed in British mills, but seldom as scholars who might have their own ideas about how to process those texts, Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book.   • B.Creating controversies in American Indological Studies

  • D.The study of Western languages only

Question 50
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A. K. Ramanujan was one of those thinkers, like Freud (whom he greatly, though not uncritically, admired), who so transform our way of looking at a subject that we are in danger of undervaluing their contribution, since we have come to take for granted precisely what they taught us, as we view the subject through their eyes. At a time when the American Indo-logical establishment regarded native Indian scholars merely as sources of information about language and texts, like the raw fiber that were taken from India to be processed in British mills, but seldom as scholars who might have their own ideas about how to process those texts, Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Raman taught them all how to weave a theory, a folktale, a poem, a book. Long before it was politically respectable, let alone politically correct, to study the works of women or of ‘illiterate’ peasants, Raman valued their poetry, their stories and their counter-systems. At a time when Indian literature meant Sanskrit, and Sanskrit meant Greek and Latin, Raman arrived in Chicago to join Edward C. Dimock and the other ‘founding fathers’ in proclaiming to the world the relevance of Tamil and Bengali and the other mother tongues. Quiz Attempt #119724

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
TheThe following table shows the total exports (in ₹ Crore) of six countries A–F over the fiveyearsfrom 2019 to 2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Note: Income = Exports – ImportsWhat was the income of all the six countries together in the year 2023 if the total imports of all these countries together was ₹770 crores in the same year?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.₹250 crores
  • B.₹320 crores
  • C.₹560 crores
  • D.₹480 crores
Correct Answer: ₹250 crores

Income = 1020 – 770 = ₹250 crores

Question 2
The following table shows the total exports (in ₹ Core) of six countries A–F over the five years from 2019 to 2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Note: Income = Exports – ImportsIn the year 2019, if the ratio of exports to imports for country D and country F are 1:2 and 4:1, respectively, then what is the total import of countries F and D together in the same year?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.₹104 crores
  • B.₹184 crores
  • C.₹192 crores
  • D.₹130 crores
Correct Answer: ₹192 crores

Imports of company D = 90 × 2 = 180 crore

Imports of company F = 484 = 12 crore

Total = 180 + 12 = 192 crore

Question 3
The following table shows the total exports (in ₹ Crore) of six countries A–F over the five years from 2019 to 2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Note: Income = Exports – ImportsIf the export of country A in the year 2024 is 20% more than the combined export of country B in 2022 and the export of country E in 2021 together, then what is the income of country A (in ₹ crore) in the year 2024, if its import is ₹184 crore for that year?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.₹106
  • B.₹44
  • C.₹92
  • D.₹68
Correct Answer: ₹68

Export of company A in 2024 = 20% of (100 + 110) = 251

Imports = 184

Income = 251 – 184 = 68 crore

Question 4
The following table shows the total exports (in ₹ Crore) of six countries A–F over the five years from 2019 to 2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Note: Income = Exports – ImportsOver all the given years, the average export of country E is _______% more than the average export of country C.(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.13711
  • B.9111
  • C.1357
  • D.1217
Correct Answer: 13711

Average exports of country E = 120+100+110+200+2205 = 150

Average exports of country C = 100+110+140+180+1305 = 132

Required percentage = 150-132132×100 = 13 711

Question 5
The following table shows the total exports (in ₹ Core) of six countries A–F over the five years from 2019 to 2023. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Note: Income = Exports – ImportsWhat is the approximate percentage increase in the export of all the countries together in the year 2022 in comparison to the year 2020?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.40.67%
  • B.72.39%
  • C.38.89%
  • D.62.99%
Correct Answer: 38.89%

Required Percentage = 750-540540×100 = 38.89%

Question 6
Reena wanted to eat an ice-cream. She took out a phone number online. She repeated the number over and over again while dialing. After the order was delivered, she forgot the number. This is an example of the use of which memory process?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Short-term memory
  • B.Automatic Processing
  • C.Echoic Memory
  • D.Iconic Memory
Correct Answer: Short-term memory

Reena repeated the number over and over while dialing and forgot it afterward — this is a classic example of:

 

  • Short-term memory (also called working memory), which:
  • Holds information for a brief period (typically 15–30 seconds).
  • Requires repetition (rehearsal) to retain temporarily.

 

If not encoded into long-term memory, it is quickly forgotten, as seen in Reena’s case.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 7
The contents of Swayamprabha channel —4 with the theme of “Education and Home Science” are provided by:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.CEC, New Delhi
  • B.IIT, Madras
  • C.IGNOU, New Delhi
  • D.IIT Delhi
Correct Answer: CEC, New Delhi

The contents of Swayamprabha channel —4 with the theme of “Education and Home Science” are provided by CEC, New Delhi.

Question 8
Which higher-order knowledge can make the difference between how well and quickly one's students learn material?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Declarative
  • B.Rote
  • C.Metacognition
  • D.Procedural
Correct Answer: Metacognition

Metacognition is the ability to think about one’s own thinking — i.e., being aware of and controlling how you learn, understand, and solve problems.

 

It is considered higher-order knowledge because it helps students:

  • Monitor their understanding,
  • Plan how to approach a learning task,
  • Evaluate their progress,
  • Adjust strategies for better results.

 

Students with strong metacognitive skills often learn faster and more effectively, as they can tailor their approach to the material.

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Question 9
Which of the following are the interactive whiteboard software that allow teachers to create digital lessons, annotate documents, and collaborate with students in real time?(a) Jamboard(b) Camtasia(c) Stormboard(d) Concept board(e) PlotagonChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.b and c only
  • B.a, c and d only
  • C.c, d and e only
  • D.a, b and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and d only

Suitable Tools as per requirement are as follows:

(a) Jamboard –

Google’s digital whiteboard tool for collaborative teaching, annotation, and brainstorming in real time.

 

(c) Stormboard –

A collaborative whiteboard platform with features for brainstorming, teaching, and real-time interaction.

 

(d) Conceptboard –

A virtual whiteboard for team collaboration, annotation, and visual learning — widely used in education and remote settings.

 

Not Suitable:

(b) Camtasia –

A screen recording and video editing software, not an interactive whiteboard.

 

(e) Plotagon –

A storytelling and animation tool, not meant for whiteboarding or live collaboration.

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 10
In which type of assessment do students measure their own progress against their previous performance rather than against external criteria or peers?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Peer Assessment
  • B.Ipsative Assessment
  • C.Formative Assessment
  • D.Summative Assessment
Correct Answer: Ipsative Assessment

Ipsative Assessment involves comparing a student’s current performance with their previous performance, focusing on individual progress over time rather than comparing with others or external benchmarks.

 

Example: A student improves their essay writing from last month to this month — the growth is measured against their own earlier work.

 

Thus, correct answer is option (B).

Question 11
Which of the following represents the epistemological orientation of quantitative research?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Interpretivism
  • B.Constructionism
  • C.Positivism
  • D.Inductivism
Correct Answer: Positivism

The epistemological orientation of quantitative research is typically positivism. Positivism is based on the idea that knowledge is derived from observable and measurable facts, and that scientific methods can provide objective, reliable results. It emphasizes testing hypotheses, using data, and relying on empirical evidence.

Interpretivism (A) and Constructionism (B) are associated with qualitative research, which focuses on understanding meaning and experiences.

Inductivism (D) is related to the process of building theories from observations, often used in qualitative research.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Positivism.

Question 12
A measure of the consistency of observations of a single situation made by different people refers to:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Construct validity
  • B.Internal validity
  • C.Split-Half reliability
  • D.Interrater reliability
Correct Answer: Interrater reliability

Interrater reliability (D) refers to the measure of consistency between different people (or raters) observing the same situation or phenomenon. It assesses how much agreement there is among multiple observers or evaluators when they assess the same thing.

Construct validity (A) refers to whether a test truly measures the concept it is intended to measure.

Internal validity (B) is concerned with whether an experiment accurately measures the relationship between variables, free from confounding factors.

Split-Half reliability (C) assesses the consistency of a test by splitting it into two parts and checking for correlation between them.

Therefore, the correct answer is (D) Interrater reliability.

Question 13
The approach in which researchers use the existing data to create groups for comparison is called:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Operational
  • B.Ex post facto
  • C.Experimental
  • D.Quasi-experimental
Correct Answer: Ex post facto

The approach in which researchers use existing data to create groups for comparison is called Ex post facto (B). In ex post facto research, the researcher looks at the effects of a variable that has already occurred, rather than manipulating an independent variable. This approach is used to explore cause-and-effect relationships after the fact, where the researcher categorizes subjects into groups based on pre-existing conditions or characteristics.

Operational (A) refers to the definition of variables in a way that they can be measured.

Experimental (C) involves manipulating variables and conducting controlled experiments.

Quasi-experimental (D) involves non-randomized comparisons but still includes some level of manipulation, unlike ex post facto.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) Ex post facto.

Question 14
Identify the nominal variables:(a) Gender(b) Annoyance level(c) Caste(d) Temperature in Kelvin(e) Economic statusChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a, b, c and d only
  • B.a and c only
  • C.b and e only
  • D.a, b, c and e only
Correct Answer: a and c only

Nominal variables are those that represent categories with no intrinsic order or ranking between them. They are simply labels for different categories.

Gender (a) and Caste (c) are both nominal variables because they represent distinct categories (e.g., male/female, or different castes) with no inherent order.

Annoyance level (b) is an ordinal variable because it represents a ranked scale (e.g., mild to severe).

Temperature in Kelvin (d) is a continuous numerical variable, not nominal.

Economic status (e) can be considered a nominal variable if it's categorized into groups like "low", "middle", and "high", but it often involves some level of ordering, making it closer to ordinal in some cases.

Thus, the correct answer is (B) a and c only.

Question 15
Arrange the probabilities corresponding to the standard normal variate ‘z' lying in the following intervals, in increasing order:(a) −∞ ≤ z ≤ +1(b) 0 ≤ z ≤ +3(c) −1 ≤ z ≤ +1(d) z ≥ +1Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.d, b, c, a
  • B.c, b, d, a
  • C.a, c, b, d
  • D.b, d, a, c
Correct Answer: d, b, c, a

A is correct answer.

−∞ ≤ z ≤ +1 = corresponding area 84.13%

0 ≤ z ≤ +3 = corresponding area 49.87%

−1 ≤ z ≤ +1 = corresponding area 68.26%

z ≥ +1 = corresponding area 15.87%

Hence the correct order is d, b, c, a

Question 16
In communication, a text is a product of:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Non-responsiveness
  • B.Military exercises
  • C.Social interaction
  • D.Neurological research
Correct Answer: Social interaction

In communication studies, a text (which can be written, spoken, visual, or multimedia) is seen as a product of social interaction because:

 

  • It is created within a cultural and social context.
  • It involves shared meanings developed through interaction between people.
  • Communication is inherently social, and texts are its tangible outcome.
Question 17
The idea that mass media do not have much power to directly influence the audience led to the concept of:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Limited effects
  • B.Mass effects
  • C.Individual effects
  • D.Regulated effects
Correct Answer: Limited effects

The Limited Effects Theory emerged from media research in the mid-20th century, especially following studies like the Lazarsfeld's "The People's Choice" (1944).

 

It suggests that mass media have minimal or limited direct influence on audiences because:

  • People are influenced more by interpersonal relationships and pre-existing beliefs.
  • Media reinforce existing attitudes rather than change them.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct

Question 18
Which of the following are considered hot media?(a) Telephone(b) Television(c) Radio(d) Cinema(e) PhotographsChoose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a, b, c only
  • B.b, c, d only
  • C.c, d, e only
  • D.a, d, e only
Correct Answer: c, d, e only

According to Marshall McLuhan, media are classified as hot or cool based on the amount of sensory data they provide and the level of audience participation they require:

 

Hot Media – Low in audience participation, rich in detail:

(c) Radio – High-definition audio, requires little audience input.

 

(d) Cinema – Rich visual and audio experience, low participation.

 

(e) Photographs – Provide detailed visual information, little interpretation needed.

 

Cool Media – Require high audience involvement:

(a) Telephone – Requires active participation; considered a cool medium.

 

(b) Television – Though rich in visuals, McLuhan classified it as cool due to lower resolution and higher audience involvement.

Question 19
Which of the following social sciences have contributed much to the knowledge of mass communication?(a) Anthropology(b) Sociology(c) Psychology(d) Social medicine(e) Defence studiesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a, d, e only
  • B.c, d, e only
  • C.b, c, d only
  • D.a, b, c only
Correct Answer: a, b, c only

The field of mass communication has been significantly enriched by several core social sciences, particularly:

 

(a) Anthropology – Helps understand cultural contexts, symbols, and rituals in communication.

 

(b) Sociology – Provides insights into social structures, audience behavior, public opinion, and media influence on society.

 

(c) Psychology – Explains how individuals perceive, process, and are influenced by media messages (e.g., persuasion, attitude change).

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 20
Match theList–IwithList–II:List I(concept)a. attention economyb. narrow castingc. synchronous audienced. peculiar form of presentnessList II (related medium)i. public speechii. televisioniii. internetiv. fm radiochoose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

List I (Concepts) vs List II (Related Mediums):

 

(a) Attention Economy → iii. Internet

The attention economy refers to the way digital platforms (especially on the internet) compete for users' limited attention — e.g., social media, YouTube algorithms.

 

(b) Narrowcasting → iv. FM Radio

Narrowcasting means sending targeted content to a specific audience segment.

 

FM Radio often serves local or niche audiences, unlike national broadcasting.

 

(c) Synchronous Audience → i. Public Speech

A synchronous audience experiences a message at the same time — like a live public speech where speaker and listeners share the moment.

 

(d) Peculiar Form of Presentness → ii. Television

The concept of "presentness" in media studies often refers to the immersive, real-time experience — especially relevant to television, where live visuals simulate presence and immediacy.

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Question 21
60 persons consume 300 kg of wheat in 40 days. In how many days will 25 persons consume 100 kg of wheat?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.28 days
  • B.30 days
  • C.32 days
  • D.35 days
Correct Answer: 32 days

Wheat consumed per person per day = 30040×60 = 0.125 kg

For 25 persons daily wheat consumption = 25 × 0.125 = 3.125 kg

No of days = 1003.125 = 32 days

Question 22
Find the next term in the number series 2A11, 4D13, 12G17, 48J23, __________:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.245N32
  • B.228L30
  • C.240M31
  • D.230M29
Correct Answer: 240M31

The next term will be 48 × 5, M, 23 + 8

i.e. 240M31

Question 23
By selling 35 eggs for Rs 30, a man loses 25%. How many eggs should he sell for Rs 144 to gain 20%?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.85
  • B.95
  • C.105
  • D.115
Correct Answer: 105

SP of 1 egg = 3035

Loss = 25%

CP = 3035×100100-25 = 87

Now to gain 20% SP = 87×1.2 = 9.67

SP of Rs 144, no of eggs = 1449.67 = 105

Question 24
In a certain coding language, the word ‘SLIGHT’ is coded as ‘UJKEJR’, then the word 'GROUND' will be coded as:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.ITQWPF
  • B.ISPVOH
  • C.IQRTOB
  • D.IPQSPB
Correct Answer: IPQSPB

G + 1 = I

R – 1 = P

O + 1 = Q

U – 1 = S

N + 1 = P

D – 1 = B

Thus, the code is IPQSPB.

Question 25
Three successive discounts of 10%, 20%, and 30% on the marked price of an item are equivalent to a single discount of:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.60%
  • B.50.4%
  • C.54.6%
  • D.49.6%
Correct Answer: 49.6%

Let MP = 100

SP = 100 × 0.9 × 0.8 × 0.7

= 50.4

Single discount = 100 – 50.4 = 49.6%

Question 26
Identify the fallacy committed in the following statement:"Water is a non-poisonous compound. Therefore, its components, oxygen and hydrogen, are non-poisonous."(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Fallacy of Division
  • B.Equivocation
  • C.Slippery Slope
  • D.Hasty Generalization
Correct Answer: Fallacy of Division

The fallacy committed in the statement "Water is a nonpoisonous compound. Therefore, its components, oxygen and hydrogen, are nonpoisonous." is the fallacy of division (A).

This fallacy occurs when it is assumed that what is true for the whole must also be true for its parts. In this case, the statement assumes that because water as a whole is nonpoisonous, its components (oxygen and hydrogen) must also be nonpoisonous, which is not true. Oxygen and hydrogen in their elemental forms can be harmful or hazardous, even though they form a nonpoisonous compound like water.

Question 27
If the statement "No monkeys are feline." is given as true, then which of the following statements can be inferred to be true?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Some monkeys are felines
  • B.Some felines are monkeys
  • C.All felines are monkeys
  • D.Some monkeys are not feline
Correct Answer: Some monkeys are not feline

If E is given as true, then A is false; I is false; O is true. Hence Some monkeys are not feline can be inferred to be true.

Question 28
Which of the following statements are logically equivalent?(a) No monkeys are felines(b) Some monkeys are felines(c) Some felines are monkeys(d) Some monkeys are not felineChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a and d only
  • B.b and c only
  • C.b and d only
  • D.b, c, and d only
Correct Answer: b and c only

Some monkeys are felines and Some felines are monkeys are CONVERSION of each other

Question 29
Which of the following two statements cannot both be true but can both be false?(a) All monkeys are apes(b) Some monkeys are apes(c) Some monkeys are not apes(d) No monkeys are apesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a and d only
  • B.a and c only
  • C.b and c only
  • D.b and d only
Correct Answer: a and d only

In the Classical Square of Opposition, contrary propositions cannot both be true, but they can both be false. Now, let's analyze the statements:

(a) All monkeys are apes: This is a universal affirmative (A-type) proposition, meaning that every monkey is an ape.

(b) Some monkeys are apes: This is a particular affirmative (I-type) proposition, meaning at least some monkeys are apes.

(c) Some monkeys are not apes: This is a particular negative (O-type) proposition, meaning there exists at least one monkey that is not an ape.

(d) No monkeys are apes: This is a universal negative (E-type) proposition, meaning no monkeys are apes.

 

Now, let's analyze:

(a) "All monkeys are apes" and (d) "No monkeys are apes" are contrary propositions, meaning they cannot both be true, but they can both be false. If some monkeys are apes and some are not, both statements would be false.

Question 30
Which of the following arguments is fallacious because the major term is all pervasive and the middle term is all-inclusive?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.The sky-lotus is fragrant because it is a lotus
  • B.Socrates is immortal because he died long ago
  • C.Sound is eternal because it is audible
  • D.Everything is nameable because it is knowable
Correct Answer: Everything is nameable because it is knowable

It is a characteristic of Anupasamhari fallacy.

 

Anupasamhari: Here the middle term is non-exclusive. The minor term is all-inclusive and leaves nothing by way of sapaksa or vipaksa; e.g., 'all things are non-eternal, because they are knowable’.

Question 31
Which of the following technologies was key to the development of second-generation electronic computers?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Vacuum tube based
  • B.Integrated Circuit (IC) based
  • C.Transistor based
  • D.Microprocessor based
Correct Answer: Transistor based

Second-generation computers (1950s-1960s) were primarily based on transistor technology, which replaced the bulky and inefficient vacuum tubes used in the first generation.

 

Transistors were smaller, more reliable, and consumed less power than vacuum tubes, leading to more compact and efficient computers.

 

The vacuum tube was the key technology in first-generation computers, Integrated Circuit (IC) technology was used in third-generation computers, and microprocessor-based systems were a hallmark of the fourth generation.

Question 32
Which of the following would create the most stable computer network with the fastest data transmission?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Use a wireless access point to connect devices
  • B.Connect devices wirelessly using a mobile phone
  • C.Use coaxial cables to connect devices in sequence
  • D.Connect devices to a switch using optic fibre cables
Correct Answer: Connect devices to a switch using optic fibre cables

Optic fiber cables offer the fastest and most stable data transmission compared to other methods due to their high bandwidth and low signal loss over long distances. Fiber optics use light signals, allowing for faster speeds and more reliable connections.

 

Wireless access points and mobile phone connections tend to be less stable and slower, with data transmission affected by interference and signal strength.

 

Coaxial cables are older and offer slower speeds than fiber optics, making them less suitable for high-performance networks.

 

Switches help in managing traffic on a network, but the type of cables used (like fiber optics) plays a crucial role in the speed and stability of the network.

Question 33
Identify the sequence of words A-E that correctly fills the blanks in the following paragraph:In the context of human-computer interaction, a _______ is an interface built around visual things, and Windows-11 is an example of an _______ with these visual things. _______ is the region of the screen used to display information. _______ is a small picture that is used to represent folders, software, etc., whereas _______ is a list of options that the user can select from.(a) OS(b) Menu(c) Window(d) Icon(e) GUIChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.e, a, c, b, d
  • B.a, e, d, c, b
  • C.e, a, c, d, b
  • D.b, c, a, e, d
Correct Answer: e, a, c, d, b

e (GUI): A Graphical User Interface (GUI) is an interface built around visual elements such as icons, windows, and menus, making it intuitive for users to interact with the system.

 

a (OS): The Operating System (OS), such as Windows 11, is the software environment that provides the graphical user interface (GUI) for users to interact with the computer.

 

c (Window): A Window is a rectangular area of the screen used to display information, such as an open application or document.

 

d (Icon): An Icon is a small picture or symbol that represents a folder, software, or other items on the screen.

 

b (Menu): A Menu is a list of options that a user can select from, commonly seen in dropdowns or sidebars within an application.

Question 34
With reference to the open source software, which of the following statements are correct?(a) It is a software that is distributed with its source code(b) It allows anyone to modify the software to best fit their needs(c) It is a software that anyone can use on a trial basis before paying for it(d) Linux is an example of open source softwareChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a, b, and d only
  • B.a, b, c, and d only
  • C.a, c, and d only
  • D.b and c only
Correct Answer: a, b, and d only

(a) Open-source software is distributed with its source code. This means users can view, modify, and distribute the software.

 

(b) Open-source software allows anyone to modify the software to best fit their needs. Users can adapt the software to their specific requirements, as long as they comply with the software's open-source license.

 

(d) Linux is a well-known example of open-source software. Its source code is available to the public, and anyone can modify and distribute it.

 

(c) This statement describes trial software (like shareware), not open-source software. Open-source software is not necessarily trial-based and is typically freely available for use and modification without any trial period or payment required.

Question 35
Match the List–I with List–IIlist I(malware types)a. trapdoorb. time bombc. polymorphic virusd. macro viruslist II(characteristics)i. produces varying but operationally equivalent copies of itselfii. code that allows unauthorized quick access at a later timeiii. instructions interpreted rather than executediv. triggers action when specified time occurschoose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • B.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
  • C.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • D.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii

(a) Trapdoor: This refers to a hidden code or instruction that allows unauthorized quick access at a later time. It's a secret entrance used by hackers or malicious users to bypass normal security. (ii) is correct here.

 

(b) Time bomb: A time bomb is malware that is set to trigger at a specified time, causing harm or a system breach when the time arrives. (iv) is correct here.

 

(c) Polymorphic virus: A polymorphic virus changes its code every time it infects a new system, but its functionality remains the same. This allows it to evade detection by traditional antivirus programs. (i) is correct here.

 

(d) Macro virus: A macro virus infects documents, especially those with macros (e.g., Word or Excel files). These viruses are usually executed when the document is opened, as the macro code is interpreted rather than executed directly by the system. (iii) is correct here.

Question 36
Which of the following Green House Gases (GHGs) considered during the second compliance period of Kyoto protocol at Doha?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Sulphur Hexafluoride (SF₆)
  • B.Hydrofluoro Carbons (HFCs)
  • C.Nitrogen Trifluoride (NF₃)
  • D.Perfluorocarbons (PFCs)
Correct Answer: Nitrogen Trifluoride (NF₃)

Option C is the correct answer.

 

In Doha, Qatar, on 8 December 2012, the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol was adopted for a second commitment period, starting in 2013 and lasting until 2020. During the Doha Amendment, Nitrogen Trifluoride (NF3) was added to the list of greenhouse gases that countries need to monitor and reduce.

Question 37
Match the List–I with List–IIList I(Particulate Matter terms)a. aerosolb. nano particlesc. smoked. fine particlesList II(Explanation)i. particles formed by incomplete combination with mixture of carbon volatilesii. particles with size less than 2.5 micro meteriii. particles with size less than 0.2 micrometeriv. any solid or liquid particle suspended in airchoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii
  • C.a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
  • D.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii

The correct answer is option (B) - a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii.

 

a. aerosol refers to any solid or liquid particles suspended in air. So, a-iv is correct.

 

b. nano particles are particles with a size less than 0.2 micrometer. So, b-iii is correct.

 

c. smoke consists of particles formed by incomplete combustion, typically a mixture of carbon and volatiles. So, c-i is correct.

 

d. fine particles typically refer to particles with a size less than 2.5 micrometer. So, d-ii is correct.

Question 38
Which of the following is an example of negative feedback in the context of climate change?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Oceans remove carbon dioxide from the air
  • B.Warming increases water vapour in air
  • C.Snow cover loss and iceshelf melt reduce sun's reflection
  • D.Global temperature increases due to global warming
Correct Answer: Oceans remove carbon dioxide from the air

Negative feedback mechanisms are those that counteract or reduce the effects of a change. In the context of climate change:

 

(A) Oceans removing carbon dioxide is an example of negative feedback because as the atmosphere warms, oceans absorb more carbon dioxide, which helps to mitigate the warming effect.

 

(B) Warming increases water vapour is a positive feedback, as water vapour is a greenhouse gas that contributes to further warming.

 

(C) Snow cover loss and ice shelf melt also represents a positive feedback, as the loss of reflective surfaces (snow and ice) leads to more absorption of heat by the Earth.

 

(D) Global temperature increases is simply the effect of global warming, not a feedback mechanism.

 

Therefore, (A) is the correct answer.

Question 39
Burning of solid waste, such as cans, batteries, plastic etc. generate:a. Microplasticsb. Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)c. Dioxinsd. Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs)e. HalonsChoose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a, b, c and d only
  • B.a, c and d only
  • C.b, d and e only
  • D.b, c and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and d only

Burning solid waste like cans, batteries, plastics, and other materials can release harmful substances, including:

 

Microplastics (a): Tiny plastic particles that can form during the burning of plastic waste.

 

Dioxins (c): Highly toxic compounds that are produced when chlorine-containing materials, such as plastics or certain industrial chemicals, are burned.

 

Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) (d): Toxic chemicals that can be released when certain materials, such as electrical equipment or plastics, are incinerated.

Question 40
Match the List–I with List–IIList I(nature of substances)a. allergensb. carcinogensc. mutagensd. teratogensList II(effect)i. substances that cause cancerii. substances that can hamper embryonic growthiii. substances that activate the immune systemiv. substances that can damage or alter genetic materialchoose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
  • B.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

Here’s how the substances match with their effects:

 

a. Allergens: Substances that activate the immune system, causing allergic reactions.

So, a-iii is correct.

 

b. Carcinogens: Substances that cause cancer.

So, b-i is correct.

 

c. Mutagens: Substances that can damage or alter genetic material.

So, c-iv is correct.

 

d. Teratogens: Substances that can hamper embryonic growth, leading to birth defects.

So, d-ii is correct.

 

Thus, the correct answer is (D) a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii.

Question 41
A British official of the East India company who was interested in higher learning in India was:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Francis Gladwin
  • B.William Ward
  • C.William Adam
  • D.William Jones
Correct Answer: William Jones

Sir William Jones was a British philologist and judge who founded the Asiatic Society of Bengal in 1784. He was deeply interested in Indian culture, languages, and history, and played a key role in promoting Oriental studies in India.

Question 42
The National Education policy, 2020 supported the idea of:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Science only education
  • B.Fragmented research
  • C.Rigorous specialization
  • D.Segregating humanities and science
Correct Answer: Rigorous specialization

Option C is the most appropriate answer among the options.

Question 43
The components of quality education identified in the National Education Policy of 2020 are:a. Political affiliationb. Curriculumc. Pedagogyd. Continuous assessmente. Higher feeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a, b only
  • B.b, c, d only
  • C.c, d, e only
  • D.a, c, e only
Correct Answer: b, c, d only

The National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 identifies key components for ensuring quality education, and these include:

 

Curriculum: Focuses on having a well-rounded, updated, and flexible curriculum.

 

Pedagogy: Emphasizes child-centered teaching methods and active learning.

 

Continuous assessment: Shifts from rote learning to ongoing assessments for a deeper understanding of the subject matter.

Question 44
Which of the following norms are prescribed for foreign universities to set up their campuses in India?a. Foreign universities must invest in the Indian manufacturing industry.b. They should have secured a position within the top 500 in global ranking.c. They should have secured a position within the top 500 in global ranking in the subject-wise category.d. They should employ only Indians for teaching and non-teaching.e. They should possess outstanding expertise in a specific area.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a, b only
  • B.b, c, d only
  • C.c, d, e only
  • D.b, c, e only
Correct Answer: b, c, e only

The correct answer is option (D) - b, c, e only.

 

For foreign universities to set up campuses in India, they are required to meet the norms that include securing a position within the top 500 in global rankings (both overall and subject-wise), as well as possessing outstanding expertise in a specific area.

Question 45
Match the List–I with List–IIList I (Five Year Plan)a. First Five Year Planb. Second Five Year Planc. Third Five Year Pland. Fifth Five Year PlanList II (Agency Setup)i. autonomous collegesii. university grants commissioniii. specialized departments of scientific studyiv. two rural institutes in wardha and mysorechoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i

Option B is the correct answer.

Question 46
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A careful study of the Rig-Veda shows that even in the early times, karma and jñāna were recognized as two separate factors in the spiritual progress of man. Karma is connected with the world immediately above the one in which we live; and jñāna is connected with the world further above that. Agni and Indra are connected with sacrifices, and the gods of the highest world are connected with prayer, and jñāna. Since the Vedic Samhitās are intimately connected with sacrifices, it is but natural that the gods connected with sacrifices, the gods of the two lower regions, should be more prominent in the Rig-Veda. It is only through jñāna that the soul can get into a state of everlasting bliss. This jñāna is esoteric knowledge. At the time of the Rig-Veda, the rṣis had evolved a highly complicated system of philosophy and that the value of jñāna as a means to final release from the world of physical bondage had been well established. The Yajur-Veda and the Sāma-Veda are of little importance to a student of ancient Indian culture. One notes the same optimistic tone in the Yajur-Veda, regarding man’s life in this world and his future in the other world. Material plenty is also quite noticeable. Gold and ornaments are spoken of freely as covetable objects. Cows are mentioned in thousands. So far as culture is concerned, so far as religion and philosophy go, there is no difference between the Rig-Veda and the other two Vedas.In Rig-veda, Agni is connected with:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.The world immediately above the one in which we live in
  • B.Sacrifices
  • C.Souls with everlasting bliss
  • D.The gods of Wisdom
Correct Answer: Sacrifices

From the passage:

 

“Agni and Indra are connected with sacrifices...”

 

Thus, option (B) is correct.

Question 47
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A careful study of the Rig-Veda shows that even in the early times, karma and jñāna were recognized as two separate factors in the spiritual progress of man. Karma is connected with the world immediately above the one in which we live; and jñāna is connected with the world further above that. Agni and Indra are connected with sacrifices, and the gods of the highest world are connected with prayer, and jñāna. Since the Vedic Samhitās are intimately connected with sacrifices, it is but natural that the gods connected with sacrifices, the gods of the two lower regions, should be more prominent in the Rig-Veda. It is only through jñāna that the soul can get into a state of everlasting bliss. This jñāna is esoteric knowledge. At the time of the Rig-Veda, the rṣis had evolved a highly complicated system of philosophy and that the value of jñāna as a means to final release from the world of physical bondage had been well established. The Yajur-Veda and the Sāma-Veda are of little importance to a student of ancient Indian culture. One notes the same optimistic tone in the Yajur-Veda, regarding man’s life in this world and his future in the other world. Material plenty is also quite noticeable. Gold and ornaments are spoken of freely as covetable objects. Cows are mentioned in thousands.   • A.Primitive culture
  • B.Predominance of sacrifice
  • C.Everlasting bliss
  • D.The gods of the highest world that are connected with sacrifices
Correct Answer: Everlasting bliss

. From the passage:

 

"It is only through jñāna that the soul can get into a state of everlasting bliss. This jñāna is esoteric knowledge."

 

This aligns with option (C).

Question 48
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A careful study of the Rig-Veda shows that even in the early times, karma and jñāna were recognized as two separate factors in the spiritual progress of man. Karma is connected with the world immediately above the one in which we live; and jñāna is connected with the world further above that. Agni and Indra are connected with sacrifices, and the gods of the highest world are connected with prayer, and jñāna. Since the Vedic Samhitās are intimately connected with sacrifices, it is but natural that the gods connected with sacrifices, the gods of the two lower regions, should be more prominent in the Rig-Veda. It is only through jñāna that the soul can get into a state of everlasting bliss. This jñāna is esoteric knowledge. At the time of the Rig-Veda, the rṣis had evolved a highly complicated system of philosophy and that the value of jñāna as a means to final release from the world of physical bondage had been well established. The Yajur-Veda and the Sāma-Veda are of little importance to a student of ancient Indian culture. One notes the same optimistic tone in the Yajur-Veda, regarding man’s life in this world and his future in the other world. Material plenty is also quite noticeable. So far as culture is concerned, so far as religion and philosophy go, there is no difference between the Rig-Veda and the other two Vedas.The optimistic tone regarding man’s life in this world and his/her future in the other world exists in:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.The Yajur-Veda
  • B.The Sāma-Veda
  • C.The Atharva Veda
  • D.Rig-Veda

"One notes the same optimistic tone in the Yajur-Veda, regarding man’s life in this world and his future in the other world."

Question 49
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A careful study of the Rig-Veda shows that even in the early times, karma and jñāna were recognized as two separate factors in the spiritual progress of man. Karma is connected with the world immediately above the one in which we live; and jñāna is connected with the world further above that. Agni and Indra are connected with sacrifices, and the gods of the highest world are connected with prayer, and jñāna. Since the Vedic Samhitās are intimately connected with sacrifices, it is but natural that the gods connected with sacrifices, the gods of the two lower regions, should be more prominent in the Rig-Veda. It is only through jñāna that the soul can get into a state of everlasting bliss. This jñāna is esoteric knowledge. At the time of the Rig-Veda, the rṣis had evolved a highly complicated system of philosophy and that the value of jñāna as a means to final release from the world of physical bondage had been well established. The Yajur-Veda and the Sāma-Veda are of little importance to a student of ancient Indian culture. One notes the same optimistic tone in the Yajur-Veda, regarding man’s life in this world and his future in the other world. Material plenty is also quite noticeable. Gold and ornaments are spoken of freely as covetable objects. Cows are mentioned in thousands. So far as culture is concerned, so far as religion and philosophy go, there is no difference between the Rig-Veda and the other two Vedas.At the time of Rig Veda, the rsis valued Jñāna as means:(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.To find signs of a gloomier side in man’s life
  • B.To sacrifice and dissociate
  • C.To find release from the world of physical bondage
  • D.To rule and regulate
Correct Answer: To find release from the world of physical bondage

“...the value of jñāna as a means to final release from the world of physical bondage had been well established.”

 

Thus, option (C) is correct.

Question 50
Read the passage carefully and answer the following questions:A careful study of the Rig-Veda shows that even in the early times, karma and jñāna were recognized as two separate factors in the spiritual progress of man. Karma is connected with the world immediately above the one in which we live; and jñāna is connected with the world further above that. Agni and Indra are connected with sacrifices, and the gods of the highest world are connected with prayer, and jñāna. Since the Vedic Samhitās are intimately connected with sacrifices, it is but natural that the gods connected with sacrifices, the gods of the two lower regions, should be more prominent in the Rig-Veda. It is only through jñāna that the soul can get into a state of everlasting bliss. This jñāna is esoteric knowledge. At the time of the Rig-Veda, the rṣis had evolved a highly complicated system of philosophy and that the value of jñāna as a means to final release from the world of physical bondage had been well established. The Yajur-Veda and the Sāma-Veda are of little importance to a student of ancient Indian culture. One notes the same optimistic tone in the Yajur-Veda, regarding man’s life in this world and his future in the other world. Material plenty is also quite noticeable. Gold and ornaments are spoken of freely as covetable objects. Cows are mentioned in thousands. So far as culture is concerned, so far as religion and philosophy go, there is no difference between the Rig-Veda and the other two Vedas.What is the original source of cultural life of the Hindus?(UGC NET 21 Aug 2024 Evening)
  • A.Itihāsas
  • B.Purāṇas
  • C.Manu
  • D.Sacred Vedas
Correct Answer: Sacred Vedas

The passage discusses at length the spiritual, philosophical, cultural, and religious significance of the Vedas, especially the Rig-Veda.

 

Thus, option (D) is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119725

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of readers of an IT magazine in the years 2019 and 2023, among the six different cities A-F. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage of Readers in Year20192023A10%15%B14%16%C17%28%D9%10%E24%9%F26%22%If the number of readers from City-C in the year 2019 and that from City-E in the year 2023 were 73,100 and 51,300, respectively, then the number of readers from City-B in the year 2023 was approximately ___________% more than that in 2019.
  • A.53.7
  • B.50.3
  • C.52.8
  • D.51.5
Correct Answer: 51.5

Readers in 2019 = 73100 × 10017 = 430000

Readers in 2023 = 51300 × 1009 = 570000

Required % = 16% of 570000-14% of 43000014% of 430000 × 100

= 51.5%

Question 2
The followingtablshows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of readers of an IT magazine in the years 2019 and 2023, among the six different cities A-F. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage of Readers in Year20192023A10%15%B14%16%C17%28%D9%10%E24%9%F26%22%If the number of readers from the City-D in the year 2019 and 2023 were 77,400 and 1,14,000respectively, then what is the difference between the number of readers from City-F in the year 2019 and that in 2023?
  • A.24,800
  • B.27,200
  • C.28,400
  • D.33,600
Correct Answer: 27,200

Readers in 2019 = 77400 × 1009 = 860000

Readers in 2023 = 114000 × 10010 = 1140000

Required difference = 22% of 1140000 – 26% of 860000

= 250800 – 223600

= 27200

Question 3
If the total number of readers from all the six cities A-F together in the year 2023 was 50,000, then the number of readers was more than 7400 in exactly ______ cities in the same year.
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.4
  • D.5
Correct Answer: 4

10% of 50000 = 5000

And 15% of 50000 = 7500

Thus, in cities A, B, C and F have readers more than 7400.

Question 4
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of readers of an IT magazine in the years 2019 and 2023, among the six different cities A-F. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage of Readers in Year20192023A10%15%B14%16%C17%28%D9%10%E24%9%F26%22%If the total number of readers from all the six cities A-F together in the years 2019 and 2023 were 4.3 lakh and 5.7 lakh, respectively, then what was the difference between the total number of readers from City-B and City-C together in the years 2019 and 2023?
  • A.1.175 lakh
  • B.1.415 lakh
  • C.1.625 lakh
  • D.1.596 lakh
Correct Answer: 1.175 lakh

Required Difference = 44% of 5.7 – 31% of 4.3

= 2.508 – 1.333

= 1.175 lakhs

Question 5
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of readers of an IT magazine in the years 2019 and 2023, among the six different cities A-F. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage of Readers in Year20192023A10%15%B14%16%C17%28%D9%10%E24%9%F26%22%If the ratio of the number of readers from City A in the year 2019 to that in 2023 was 2:5, then what wasthe ratio of the number of readers from all six cities together in the year 2019 to that in 2023?
  • A.3:5
  • B.4:5
  • C.4:9
  • D.2:5
Correct Answer: 3:5

. 10% of x 15% of y = 25

or xy = 3 : 5

Question 6
What is the base-10 equivalent of the base-4 number 3013?
  • A.182
  • B.196
  • C.199
  • D.190
Correct Answer: 199

(3013)4 = 3 × 43 + 0 × 42 + 1 × 41 + 3 × 40

= 199

Question 7
Which of the following are the subdivisions ofImplicit (Unconscious) memory?A. PrimingB.Classical conditioning effectsC. Episodic MemoryD. Semantic MemoryE. Procedural MemoryChoose the most appropriate answer from the optionsgiven below:
  • A.B and D only
  • B.A, C and E only
  • C.A, B, D and E only
  • D.A, B, C, D and E
Correct Answer: A, B, D and E only

The correct answer is (C) A, B, D and E only.

 

Implicit (unconscious) memory includes priming (A), where exposure to one stimulus influences the response to another; classical conditioning effects (B), which involve learning through associations; semantic memory (D), which stores general knowledge and facts; and procedural memory (E), which relates to skills and tasks. Episodic memory (C), on the other hand, is a form of explicit (conscious) memory that involves the recollection of specific events or experiences, making it not a subdivision of implicit memory.

Question 8
Identify the correct sequence of the following research organisations accordingto their year of establishment.A. Indian Council of Social Science Research (ICSSR)B. National Council for Rural Institutes (NCRI)C. Indian Council for Philosophical Research (ICPR)D. Indian Councilfor Historical Research (ICHR)E. Indian Institute of Advanced Studies (IAS)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D, E, B, C
  • B.B, E, C, D, A
  • C.E, A, D, C, B
  • D.C, B, A, E, D
Correct Answer: E, A, D, C, B

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Indian Institute of Advanced Study (IIAS) – established in the year 1965.

Indian Council of Social Science Research (ICSSR) – established in the year 1969.

Indian Council for Historical Research (ICHR) – established in the year 1972.

Indian Council for Philosophical Research (ICPR) – established in the year 1977.

National Council for Rural Institutes (NCRI) – established in the year 1995.

Question 9
The second five-year plan for implementation included the recommendations of the following:A.University Education CommissionB. Languages Commission of IndiaC. Rural Higher Education CommitteeD. Committee on Establishment of New UniversitiesE. Three-Year Degree Course CommitteeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, B and E only
Correct Answer: C, D and E only

Option C is the correct answer. The second Five-Year Plan was implemented for the year 1956 to 1961. University Education Commission and Languages Commission of India recommendations were not included in the second FYP.

 

The University Education Commission was set up in 1948 under the Chairmanship of Dr. S Radhakrishnan "to report on Indian university education and suggest improvements and extensions that might be desirable to suit the present and future needs and aspirations of the country".

 

The Official Languages Commission is to be established by the President in accordance with Article 344 of the Indian Constitution. The commission was constituted in 1955 via a notification of the Ministry of Home Affairs.

 

In 1954, the Government established a Rural Higher Education Committee at the centre and gave it the responsibility to organize rural education.

 

Report of the Experts Committee Appointed to Consider the Establishment of new Universities was appointed in 1953.

 

Three-Year Degree Course Committee submitted its report in 1958.

Question 10
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Types of toxicants)A. NephrotoxicB.HematotoxicC.PulmonotoxicD. HepatotoxicList – II (Affected Organ)I. LungsII. KidneyIII. LiverIV. BloodChoose the correct answer from the optionsgiven below:
  • A.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • B.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
  • C.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • D.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
Correct Answer: A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Hematotoxic: Chemically induced toxicity in the blood.

Hepatotoxic: Toxic Effects on the Liver.

Nephrotoxic: Toxic Responses of the Kidney.

Pulmonotoxic: Medical name for side effects on the lungs.

Question 11
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Concept)A.Free commerce and communicationB. Communication ineconomicsC. Language as a conduit of communicationD. Lines of communicationList – II (Source)I. Alfred MarshallII. John LockeIII. Karl MarxIV. Adam SmithChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • B.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III

The correct answer is (D) A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III.

 

A. Free commerce and communication (IV) is associated with Adam Smith, who emphasized free trade in economics.

B. Communication in economics (I) relates to Alfred Marshall, known for his contributions to economic theory and communication within economics.

C. Language as a conduit of communication (II) connects to John Locke, who discussed the role of language in conveying ideas.

D. Lines of communication (III) corresponds to Karl Marx, who analyzed how communication affects social relations and class struggle.

Question 12
Which of the following are essential requirements for the formation of photochemical SMOG?A. Carbon monoxide (CO)B. Nitrogen dioxide (NO2)C. Carbon dioxide (CO2)D. Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)E. SunlightChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D only
  • B.A, C and E only
  • C.B, C, D and E only
  • D.B, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, D and E only

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Photochemical Smog (Los Angeles Smog or Oxidizing Smog): This type of smog is primarily associated with sunny, urban areas with high levels of vehicle emissions. It forms when nitrogen oxides (NOx) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from vehicle exhaust and industrial sources react with sunlight. These reactions produce ground-level ozone (O3) and other secondary pollutants, creating a brownish haze. Photochemical smog is known to cause respiratory problems, eye irritation, and reduced lung function, among other health issues.

Question 13
When you try to predict the value of an outcome variable from one or more variables, you are likely to be using:A. The Pearson product-moment correlationB. Bivariate regressionC. Multivariate regressionD. Analysis of varianceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.A and D only
Correct Answer: B and C only

When predicting an outcome variable from one or more variables, bivariate regression is used for one predictor and multivariate regression for multiple predictors. Pearson correlation measures relationships, and ANOVA compares group means. Hence, the correct answer is (C) B and C only.

Question 14
Speed of a boat in still water is 5 km/hr and the speed of the stream is 1 km/hr. A man rows to a place at a distance of 24 km and comes back to the starting point. Find the total time taken by him.
  • A.8 hr
  • B.10 hr
  • C.12 hr
  • D.15 hr
Correct Answer: 10 hr

Total Time = 245+1 + 245-1 = 4 + 6 = 10 hours

Question 15
When communication helps a group to achieve its goals, it is known as:
  • A.Disruptive role
  • B.Counteractive role
  • C.Promotive role
  • D.Devotional role
Correct Answer: Promotive role

When communication helps a group achieve its goals, it plays a promotive role as it encourages productive interaction and cooperation toward shared objectives. The other roles may hinder or redirect group progress. Hence, the correct answer is (C) Promotive role.

Question 16
Which of the following digital initiatives provides a database of profiles of scientists/researchers and other faculty members working at leading academic institutions and R&D organizations?
  • A.SWAYAM Prabha
  • B.National Academic Depository (NAD)
  • C.E-Vidwan
  • D.E-ShodhSindhu
Correct Answer: E-Vidwan

Option C is the correct answer.

 

VIDWAN is the premier database of profiles of scientists / researchers and other faculty members working at leading academic institutions and other R & D organisation involved in teaching and research in India. It provides important information about expert's background, contact address, experience, scholarly publications, skills and accomplishments, researcher identity, etc. The database developed and maintained by Information and Library Network Centre (INFLIBNET) with financial support from the National Mission on Education through ICT (NME-ICT). The database would be instrumental in selection of panels of experts for various committees, taskforce, established by the Ministries / Govt. establishments for monitoring and evaluation purposes.

Question 17
Which technology first marked a separation between transportation and communication?
  • A.Telegraph
  • B.Projection
  • C.Printing
  • D.Photography
Correct Answer: Telegraph

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The telegraph was the first technology to separate transportation and communication. Before the telegraph, communication relied heavily on the physical transportation of messages via ships, horses, or trains. Information could only travel as fast as people or goods could be transported.

 

When the telegraph was invented in the 19th century, it allowed messages to be sent over long distances almost instantly through electrical signals, without needing physical movement of objects or people. This marked the first significant technological distinction between the act of communicating information and the act of transporting goods or people.

Question 18
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Digital Initiative)A.ShodhSindhuB.ShodhGangotriC.ShodhShuddhiD. FOSSEEList – II (Purpose)I. Hosts synopsis of research topics in Indian UniversitiesII. Free/Libre and open-source software for EducationIII. Provides access to e-resources to Universities and CollegesIV. Plagiarism checking initiative aimed to ensure originality in academic writingsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • C.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • D.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
Correct Answer: A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II

The correct match is given below.

 

A. Shodh Sindhu - III. Provides access to e-resources to Universities and Colleges

B. Shodh Gangotri - I. Hosts synopsis of research topics in Indian Universities

C. Shodh Shuddhi - IV. Plagiarism checking initiative aimed to ensure originality in academic writings

D. FOSSEE - II. Free/Libre and Open Source Software for Education

Question 19
If a research project is set up so that everybody in the population of interest has an equal chance of being included in thesample, the research involves:
  • A.Quota sampling
  • B.Probability sampling
  • C.Judgemental sampling
  • D.Convenience sampling
Correct Answer: Probability sampling

When everyone in the population has an equal chance of being included in the sample, it refers to probability sampling, which ensures random selection and reduces bias. The other sampling methods involve non-random selection. Hence, the correct answer is (B) Probability sampling.

Question 20
Arrange the different stages involved in the process ofdeduction in correct sequence.A. Revision of theoryB. Hypothesis confirmed or rejectedC. FindingsD. Data CollectionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, D, C
  • B.D, C, B, A
  • C.A, C, B, D
  • D.B, D, A, C
Correct Answer: D, C, B, A

In the process of deduction, the correct sequence is: data is collected (D), findings are derived (C), the hypothesis is confirmed or rejected based on the findings (B), and the theory is revised if necessary (A). Hence, the correct answer is option (B) – D, C, B, A.

Question 21
Arrange the following fractions in increasing order.A. 6/7​B. 11/13C. 16/19D. 19/22Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.D, C, B, A
  • C.C, B, A, D
  • D.D, A, B, C
Correct Answer: C, B, A, D

Option C is the correct answer. The correct order is – C, B, A, D.

Question 22
The media accountability system to improve media quality focuses on:A. EvaluationB. Audience controlC. MonitoringD. EducationE. FeedbackChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C, D and E only
  • D.A, B, C, D and E
Correct Answer: A, C, D and E only

Bertrand has defined media accountability system as 'any non-state means of making media responsible to the public'. The main general means he identifies are training, evaluation (criticism of performance); monitoring; and feedback (to and from the public).

Question 23
Which of thefollowing statements are true?A. Validity can never apply to any single proposition by itself.B. The concept of truth can apply to single propositions.C. Propositions by themselves can be valid but not invalid.D. Proposition cannot be valid by itself though it can be invalid on its own.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.D only
  • B.A and B only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.B and D only
Correct Answer: A and B only

Only Statements A and B are true. Validity refers to the logical structure of an argument, not individual propositions, whereas truth can apply to single propositions. A proposition cannot be valid or invalid on its own but can be true or false.

Question 24
Choose the correct statements:A. x% of y is equal to y% of 100x.B. If 40% of 60% of 3/5 of a number is 504, then 25% of 2/5of that number is equal to 350.C. If Ais 15% more than B, then B is ~13.04% less than A.D. 10% of 5 and 5% of 10 add-up to 0.1.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.C and D only
  • D.A and D only
Correct Answer: B and C only

A. x% of y = xy100

y% of 100x = xy

 

B. Number = 504 × 53 × 10060 × 10040 = 3500

25% of 2/5 of that number = 25100 × 25 × 3500 = 350

 

C. A = 1.15 B

The, B = 11.15 A = 0.8696 A

A – B = A – 0.8696 A = 0.1304 A

Percentage reduction = 0.1304AA × 100 = 13.04%

 

D. A0% of 5 + 5% of 10 = 0.5 + 0.5 = 1

 

Thus, only B and C are correct.

Question 25
Which of the following is the first post-Independence education commission in India?
  • A.Indian Education Commission
  • B.Calcutta University Commission
  • C.University Education Commission
  • D.Indian Universities Commission
Correct Answer: University Education Commission

Option C is the correct answer.

 

After independence, the first significant step taken by the Government of India in the field of education was the appointment of the “University Education Commission” in 1948 under the Chairmanship of Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, a distinguished scholar and former vice-chancellor of Banaras Hindu University and who became the second President of India.

Question 26
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Words)A. FINDB. CLOGC. SHOWD. TIMEList – II (Codes with same rule)I. RGKCII. DGLBIII. AJMEIV.QFMUChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I

Option B is the correct answer.

 

FIND (A-II: DGLB): Compare the letters in "FIND" with "DGLB":

F → D (Shift by -2 in the alphabet)

I → G (Shift by -2)

N → L (Shift by -2)

D → B (Shift by -2)

 

So, "FIND" is encoded by shifting each letter backward by 2 positions, resulting in "DGLB."

 

CLOG (B-III: AJME): Compare the letters in "CLOG" with "AJME":

C → A (Shift by -2)

L → J (Shift by -2)

O → M (Shift by -2)

G → E (Shift by -2)

 

"CLOG" follows the same -2 shift pattern to become "AJME."

 

SHOW (C-IV: QFMU): Compare the letters in "SHOW" with "QFMU":

S → Q (Shift by -2)

H → F (Shift by -2)

O → M (Shift by -2)

W → U (Shift by -2)

 

"SHOW" is also encoded with the same rule, giving "QFMU."

 

TIME (D-I: RGKC): Compare the letters in "TIME" with "RGKC":

T → R (Shift by -2)

I → G (Shift by -2)

M → K (Shift by -2)

E → C (Shift by -2)

 

"TIME" is encoded as "RGKC" by shifting each letter backward by 2 positions.

Question 27
Which of thefollowing statement is correct?
  • A.Nyāyasyllogism has three propositions.
  • B.Nyaya syllogism has five terms.
  • C.Nyaya syllogism has five propositions.
  • D.Nyaya syllogism has three propositions and three terms.
Correct Answer: Nyaya syllogism has three propositions and three terms.

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The Nyaya syllogism has 5 and the Aristotelian has 3 propositions. However, the terms in both are only 3 - the sädhya or the major, the paksa or the minor and the hetu or the middle.

Question 28
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Goals / Targets of MDGs and SDGs)A. Goalsin Millennium Development GoalsB. Targetsin Millennium Development GoalsC. Goals in Sustainable Development GoalsD. Targets in Sustainable Development GoalsList – II (Number of Goals / Targets)I. 8II. 17III. 21IV.169Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-II, B-I, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • C.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
  • D.A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III
Correct Answer: A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Goal in MDGs – 8

Targets in MDGs – 21

Goal in SDGs – 17

Targets in SDGs – 169

 

The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) were a set of 8 global goals established in 2000 by the United Nations, with a target to be achieved by 2015. These goals aimed to address a range of global issues, from poverty to environmental sustainability.

 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) replaced the MDGs in 2015, with a broader and more ambitious agenda. The SDGs consist of 17 goals to be achieved by 2030, focusing on a more inclusive and comprehensive approach to development.

Question 29
Which of the following statements is logically equivalent to the statement – “No horses are feline”?
  • A.No feline are horses
  • B.No horses are non-feline
  • C.All non-horses are felines
  • D.All non-felines are horses
Correct Answer: No feline are horses

Option A – ‘No feline are horses’ – is logically equivalent to the given statement – ‘No horses are feline’

Question 30
Which fallacy is committed in the following statement?“People with cases of flu should be kept in quarantine, because ithas never been disproven as thebest means of keeping the disease from spreading.”
  • A.Appeal to Ignorance
  • B.Hasty Generalization
  • C.Slippery Slope
  • D.False cause
Correct Answer: Appeal to Ignorance

The fallacy in the statement is appeal to ignorance (A), as it argues that something is true simply because it has not been disproven, rather than providing positive evidence for the claim. Hence, the correct answer is (A) Appeal to Ignorance.

Question 31
Which of the following is the National Coordinator of SWAYAM courses for non-technical post-graduation education?
  • A.All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE)
  • B.National Institute of Technical Teachers Training and Research (NITTTR)
  • C.National Council of Educational Research and Training (NCERT)
  • D.University Grants Commission (UGC)
Correct Answer: University Grants Commission (UGC)

Option D is the correct answer.

 

SWAYAM (Study Webs of Active-Learning for Young Aspiring Minds) is an initiative introduced by the Ministry of Education. It's an online platform that offers free online courses and learning materials. The courses on SWAYAM cover a wide range of subjects and levels, including school-level courses (from class 9), undergraduate and postgraduate courses, and various skill development programs.

 

National Coordinators are the Institutions that have been so designated by the Ministry and assigned a specific sector or preparation of online courses for SWAYAM. The list of 9 National Coordinators is:

(i) ICTE (All India Council for Technical Education) for self-paced and international courses

(ii) NPTEL (National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning) for Engineering

(iii) UGC (University Grants Commission) for non technical post-graduation education

(iv) CEC (Consortium for Educational Communication) for under-graduate education

(v) NCERT (National Council of Educational Research and Training) for school education

(vi) NIOS (National Institute of Open Schooling) for school education

(vii) IGNOU (Indira Gandhi National Open University) for out-of-school students

(viii) IIMB (Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore) for management studies

(ix) NITTTR (National Institute of Technical Teachers Training and Research) for Teacher Training programme.

Question 32
A motor boat covers a certain distance downstream in 5 hours but takes 6 hours to return upstream to the starting point. If the speed of the stream be 4 km/h, then what is the speed of the motor boat in still water?
  • A.40 km/h
  • B.42 km/h
  • C.44 km/h
  • D.46 km/h
Correct Answer: 44 km/h

Let Boat speed = x km/hr

Then, upstream speed = x – 4 km/hr

Downstream speed = x + 4 km/hr

Let total distance = y

Then, x – 4 = y6 ----------(i)

Also x + 4 = y5 -----------(ii)

Solving (i) and (ii), we get

y = 240 and x = 44

Thus, speed of motor boat = 44km/hr

Question 33
What is the full form of POPs?
  • A.Persistent Organic Pollutants
  • B.Persistent Oxygenated Pollutants
  • C.Polycyclic Organic Pollutants
  • D.Polymerised Organic Pollutants
Correct Answer: Persistent Organic Pollutants

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) are a class of highly toxic chemicals that remain in the environment for long periods and can have significant adverse effects on human health and ecosystems. POPs are resistant to environmental degradation through chemical, biological, and photolytic processes, allowing them to persist in the environment. They can accumulate in the fatty tissues of living organisms and move through the food chain, affecting both wildlife and humans.

 

Examples of POPs include DDT (a pesticide), Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), Dioxins.

Question 34
Identify the correct order of the following list of computer components ranked from slowest to fastest in terms of access time.A. CPU cacheB. RAMC. SSDD. Optical DriveChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, C, B, A
  • B.A, B, C, D
  • C.(C) B, D, A, C
  • D.(D) C, A, D, B
Correct Answer: D, C, B, A

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The correct order of the computer components ranked from slowest to fastest in terms of access time is:

 

Optical Drive (D): Optical drives (e.g., CD/DVD drives) are the slowest among these components in terms of access time because they rely on mechanical movement and read speeds.

 

SSD (C): Solid State Drives (SSDs) are much faster than optical drives because they use flash memory, which has quicker access times than mechanical storage.

 

RAM (B): Random Access Memory (RAM) is faster than SSDs as it allows for very quick read and write access to data being actively used by the CPU.

 

CPU Cache (A): The CPU cache is the fastest memory available, as it is located on the CPU chip itself and allows for extremely quick access to frequently used data.

Question 35
Match List – I with List– II.List – I (Ancient Treatises)A. LilavatiB. Yoga-SutrasC. Nyaya-SutrasD.ArthashastraList – II (Author)I. ChanakyaII. GautamIII. PatanjaliIV.BhaskaracharyaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
