  • B.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • C.B-I, D-III, A-II, C-IV
  • D.C-II, D-I, A-IV, B-III
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I

Option A is the correct answer.

 

A. Lilavati – Treatises on Mathematics, written by Bhaskaracharya.

B. Yoga-Sutras – Treatises on Yoga, written by Patanjali.

C. Nyaya-Sutras – Treatises on Logic by Gautam

D. Arthashastra – Treatises on statecraft, political science, economic policy, and military strategy.

Question 36
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Use)A. To input voiceovers for a presentationB. To input a PINC.To select options from a menuD. To operate a flight simulatorList – II (Appropriate Computer Input Device)I. MouseII. JoystickIII. MicrophoneIV. Number padChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • B.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • C.A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The correct match is given below.

A. To input voiceovers for a presentation → III. Microphone (A microphone is used to capture audio, including voiceovers.)

B. To input a PIN → IV. Number pad (A number pad is used for entering numeric values like a PIN.)

C. To select options from a menu → I. Mouse (A mouse is commonly used for selecting options on a screen.)

D. To operate a flight simulator → II. Joystick (A joystick is typically used for controlling flight simulators.)

Question 37
Knowing that you find algebra more difficult than your sister does, but that you could improve with practice, is an example of:
  • A.Self-Regulation
  • B.Metacognition
  • C.Self-discipline
  • D.Automation
Correct Answer: Metacognition

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Metacognition refers to the awareness and understanding of one’s own thought processes. In this case, recognizing that you find algebra more difficult than your sister does, along with the awareness that you could improve with practice, demonstrates metacognitive skills. You are reflecting on your understanding of your own learning and performance.

Question 38
A device used to convert a computer’s digital signal to an analogue signal for communication is called a:
  • A.bridge
  • B.switch
  • C.modem
  • D.Network Interface Card (NIC)
Correct Answer: modem

Option C is the correct answer.

 

A modem (modulator-demodulator) is a device that converts digital signals from a computer into analog signals for transmission over telephone lines and vice versa. This is essential for enabling communication over analog communication systems

Question 39
Match List – I withList – II.List – I (Abbreviation)A. et.al.B. ante.C. cf.D. ibid.List – II (Meaning)I. in the same placeII. and othersIII. beforeIV compareChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
Correct Answer: A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I

The correct matching is:

 

A. et al. (II) - and others

B. ante. (III) - before

C. cf. (IV) - compare

D. ibid. (I) - in the same place

 

Thus, the correct answer is (B) A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I.

Question 40
According to National Credit Framework (NCTF), after obtaining Bachelor’s Degree (Honours / Research/Engineering) of programme duration of4years, the credit level earned is:
  • A.5.5
  • B.6
  • C.6.5
  • D.7
Correct Answer: 6

Option B is the correct answer.

 

In April 2023, the University Grants Commission announced the implementation of the National Credit Framework (NCrF) for all regulatory organisations and universities in India. This framework is designed to integrate the credits earned through school education, higher education, vocational, and skill education, and provide lifelong learning opportunities.

 

According to the framework, an academic year will be defined by the number of hours a student puts in and credits will be provided to them accordingly at the end of each academic year. NCrF is a meta-framework that consists of 3 verticals:

1. National School Education Qualification Framework (NSEQF)

2. National Higher Education Qualification Framework (NHEQF), and

3. National Skills Qualification Framework (NSQF).

 

Credit Levels: The NCrF has proposed several levels within this framework ranging from level 1 to level 8. The credit level that can be attained after completion of school education, i.e., grade 5th will be level 1, grade 8th will be level 2, grade 10th will be level 3, and grade 12th will be level 4. Higher education shall be from credit levels of 4.5 to level 8 (Under Graduate Levels 4.5, 5.0, 5.5 & 6.0, Post Graduate Levels 6.0, 6.5 & 7.0, and PhD Level 8), and for vocational education & training level 1 to level 8.

 

The total Credit Points earned by a student can be calculated by multiplying the credits earned by the NCrF Level associated with those credits. These credit points can be redeemed according to the guidelines of the Academic Bank of Credit (ABC) for admission into various educational programs, including school, higher education, technical, or vocational courses. This system facilitates both horizontal and vertical mobility and offers multiple lateral entry options.

Question 41
Which of the following statements A-D about computer memory size is/are true?A. 25 KB is larger than 100 MB.B. 999 MB is larger than 50 GB.C. 3500 KB is smaller than 2 GB.D. 2350 bytes is smaller than2 KB.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A only
  • B.C only
  • C.B and D only
  • D.B and C only
Correct Answer: C only

Only Statement C is correct. Rest all the statements are incorrect.

Question 42
‘Mind to mind’ communication involves the communication of meanings through:A. Physical settingsB. Shared beliefsC. ValuesD. Noise manipulationE. ContextChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, B, C and E only
  • D.C, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and E only

Mind to mind communication refers to the exchange of meanings through non-verbal and contextual factors, such as shared beliefs, values, and context, which shape understanding between individuals. Physical settings also play a role. Hence, the correct answer is (C) A, B, C and E only.

Question 43
Which of the following approaches to the study of reality suggests that only knowledge gained through experience and the senses is acceptable?
  • A.Constructionism
  • B.Empiricism
  • C.Ethnography
  • D.Operationalism
Correct Answer: Empiricism

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Empiricism is a philosophical approach that asserts that knowledge comes primarily from sensory experience. It emphasizes observation and experimentation as the foundations of understanding reality.

Question 44
Arrange the following in order of increasing connotation.A. FielderB. Ball PlayerC. Baseball PlayerD. AthleteChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C, A, D
  • B.B, A, C, D
  • C.D, B, C, A
  • D.A, C, B, D
Correct Answer: D, B, C, A

The order of increasing connotation (from more general to more specific) is: Athlete (general term), Ball Player (refers to a player in any ball game), Baseball Player (specific to baseball), and Fielder (a specific position in baseball). Hence, the correct answer is (C) D, B, C, A.

Question 45
Which of the following are true about breeder reactors?A. They produce more fissile material than they consume.B. There are no breeder reactors in India.C. There are two types (Fastand Slow) of breeder reactors.D. For breeding operation, the conversion ratio (fissile material produced/fissile material consumed) should be more than one.E. Breeder reactors produce more nuclear waste than the conventional one.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C and D only
  • B.A, B and D only
  • C.B, C and E only
  • D.A, C, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, C and D only

Option A is the correct answer. Statement A, C and D are correct.

 

India has inaugurated its first indigenous Fast Breeder Reactor (500 MWe) at Kalpakkam, Tamil Nadu in March 2024.

 

A breeder reactor is a nuclear reactor that generates more fissile material than it consumes. These reactors can be fueled with more-commonly available isotopes of uranium and thorium, such as uranium-238 and thorium-232, as opposed to the rare uranium-235 which is used in conventional reactors. The most common breeding is of Plutonium-239.

 

There are two categories of breeder reactors, based on the speed of the neutrons. Fast breeder reactors which use uranium-238 as fuel and thermal breeder reactors which use thorium-232 as fuel. Fast breeders do not require moderation since the neutrons need to be moving fast, whereas thermal breeders make us of moderation to achieve slower-moving neutrons.

 

An important concept for a breeder reactor is how much fissionable fuel is being produced compared to how much fuel is being used. This is known as the breeding ratio. For example for the breeding of plutonium, the ratio would be the amount of plutonium produced to the amount of uranium-235 used.

Question 46
Read the paragraph and answer the following question.According to a World Health Organization report, about 80 percent of the world population uses traditional medicine systems in some or the other way. India has a distinctive and unique traditional medicine base, with each system having its own ancient philosophy, medicinal knowledge, perception and practices that align with the regional cultures, traditions and beliefs. The traditional medicine systems in India include Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy,Unani, Siddha, SowaRigpaand Homeopathy which is known as AYUSH. All thesesystems were formulated, practiced and perfected in a continuum much before the advent of modern health science.In many countries of the world, medical pluralism is the norm and traditional medicine is one of the surest means to achieve total healthcare coverage for the world population using acceptable, safe and economically-feasible methods. No system of medicine can single-handedly address all health concerns, but an integrative approach incorporating the positives of each can surely benefit mankind. The holistic patient-centeredand individualised approach is the trademark of traditional systems and enables the patient-physician partnership to design or customise treatment and lifestyle advice in order to achieve the highest potential for well-being. This awareness combined with the increase in use of traditional medicine has brought the systems to the fore. The diverse activities ranging from the provision of prophylactic care to the management of disease and the effective implementation and integration of AYUSHsystem to the public healthcare during the pandemic has garnered global attention to AYUSHsystems. This has enabled the signing of the Host Country Agreement for the establishment of Global Centre for Traditional Medicine (GCTM) at Jamnagar.In many countries of the world, medical pluralism is the norm because:
  • A.Traditional systems of medicine are useless.
  • B.Traditional systems of medicine befool the public.
  • C.An integrative approach incorporating the positives, of each system of medicine can in no way benefit mankind.
  • D.No single system of medicine can single-handedly address all health concerns
Correct Answer: No single system of medicine can single-handedly address all health concerns

The correct answer is option D.

 

The paragraph discusses how medical pluralism, which refers to the coexistence of different medical systems, is common in many countries. It emphasizes that no single medical system can address all health concerns by itself. Instead, an integrative approach that combines the strengths of various systems (like traditional and modern medicine) is beneficial for healthcare coverage. Therefore, option (D) aligns with the information in the paragraph.

Question 47
Read the paragraph and answer the following question.According to a World Health Organization report, about 80 percent of the world population uses traditional medicine systems in some or the other way. India has a distinctive and unique traditional medicine base, with each system having its own ancient philosophy, medicinal knowledge, perception and practices that align with the regional cultures, traditions and beliefs. The traditional medicine systems in India include Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy,Unani, Siddha, SowaRigpaand Homeopathy which is known as AYUSH. All thesesystems were formulated, practiced and perfected in a continuum much before the advent of modern health science.In many countries of the world, medical pluralism is the norm and traditional medicine is one of the surest means to achieve total healthcare coverage for the world population using acceptable, safe and economically-feasible methods. No system of medicine can single-handedly address all health concerns, but an integrative approach incorporating the positives of each can surely benefit mankind. The holistic patient-centeredand individualised approach is the trademark of traditional systems and enables the patient-physician partnership to design or customise treatment and lifestyle advice in order to achieve the highest potential for well-being. This awareness combined with the increase in use of traditional medicine has brought the systems to the fore. The diverse activities ranging from the provision of prophylactic care to the management of disease and the effective implementation and integration of AYUSHsystem to the public healthcare during the pandemic has garnered global attention to AYUSHsystems. This has enabled the signing of the Host Country Agreement for the establishment of Global Centre for Traditional Medicine (GCTM) at Jamnagar.Which of the following facts about the traditional Indian medicine systems are false?A. Each system is Unique.B. They include Ayurveda,Naturopathy, Yoga,Unani,Siddha,SowaRigpaand homeopathy.C. Modern Health Science preceded them.D. Each system has an essentially similar philosophy.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below
  • A.A, B, and D only
  • B.B and C
  • C.C and D only
  • D.B, C and D
Correct Answer: C and D only

Statement C ("Modern Health Science preceded them"): This is false. The paragraph clearly states that these traditional systems were formulated and practiced "much before the advent of modern health science."

 

Statement D ("Each system has an essentially similar philosophy"): This is false. The paragraph emphasizes that each system has its own philosophy, aligning with regional cultures, traditions, and beliefs, which implies their distinctiveness rather than similarity.

 

Hence, the statements C and D are false, making option (C) C and D only the correct answer.

Question 48
Read the paragraph and answer the following question.According to a World Health Organization report, about 80 percent of the world population uses traditional medicine systems in some or the other way. India has a distinctive and unique traditional medicine base, with each system having its own ancient philosophy, medicinal knowledge, perception and practices that align with the regional cultures, traditions and beliefs. The traditional medicine systems in India include Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy,Unani, Siddha, SowaRigpaand Homeopathy which is known as AYUSH. All thesesystems were formulated, practiced and perfected in a continuum much before the advent of modern health science.In many countries of the world, medical pluralism is the norm and traditional medicine is one of the surest means to achieve total healthcare coverage for the world population using acceptable, safe and economically-feasible methods. No system of medicine can single-handedly address all health concerns, but an integrative approach incorporating the positives of each can surely benefit mankind. The holistic patient-centeredand individualised approach is the trademark of traditional systems and enables the patient-physician partnership to design or customise treatment and lifestyle advice in order to achieve the highest potential for well-being. This awareness combined with the increase in use of traditional medicine has brought the systems to the fore. The diverse activities ranging from the provision of prophylactic care to the management of disease and the effective implementation and integration of AYUSHsystem to the public healthcare during the pandemic has garnered global attention to AYUSHsystems. This has enabled the signing of the Host Country Agreement for the establishment of Global Centre for Traditional Medicine (GCTM) at Jamnagar.According to a World Health Organization report, the percentage of the world population that uses traditional medicine systemsin some way or the other is:
  • A.About 20%
  • B.About 50%
  • C.About 100%
  • D.About 80%
Correct Answer: About 80%

The correct answer is option (D) - About 80%.

 

The paragraph clearly states that "according to a World Health Organization report, about 80 percent of the world population uses traditional medicine systems in some way or the other." This directly matches option (D). Therefore, the correct percentage of the world population using traditional medicine systems is about 80%.

Question 49
Read the paragraph and answer the following question.According to a World Health Organization report, about 80 percent of the world population uses traditional medicine systems in some or the other way. India has a distinctive and unique traditional medicine base, with each system having its own ancient philosophy, medicinal knowledge, perception and practices that align with the regional cultures, traditions and beliefs. The traditional medicine systems in India include Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy,Unani, Siddha, SowaRigpaand Homeopathy which is known as AYUSH. All thesesystems were formulated, practiced and perfected in a continuum much before the advent of modern health science.In many countries of the world, medical pluralism is the norm and traditional medicine is one of the surest means to achieve total healthcare coverage for the world population using acceptable, safe and economically-feasible methods. No system of medicine can single-handedly address all health concerns, but an integrative approach incorporating the positives of each can surely benefit mankind. The holistic patient-centeredand individualised approach is the trademark of traditional systems and enables the patient-physician partnership to design or customise treatment and lifestyle advice in order to achieve the highest potential for well-being. This awareness combined with the increase in use of traditional medicine has brought the systems to the fore. The diverse activities ranging from the provision of prophylactic care to the management of disease and the effective implementation and integration of AYUSHsystem to the public healthcare during the pandemic has garnered global attention to AYUSHsystems. This has enabled the signing of the Host Country Agreement for the establishment of Global Centre for Traditional Medicine (GCTM) at Jamnagar.The Global Centre for Traditional Medicine has been established in:
  • A.World Health Organization
  • B.Jamnagar
  • C.New Delhi
  • D.Haridwar
Correct Answer: Jamnagar

The correct answer is option (B) - Jamnagar.

 

The paragraph states, "The signing of the Host Country Agreement for the establishment of Global Centre for Traditional Medicine (GCTM) at Jamnagar." This clearly indicates that the Global Centre for Traditional Medicine has been established in Jamnagar, making option (B) the correct answer.

Question 50
Read the paragraph and answer the following question.According to a World Health Organization report, about 80 percent of the world population uses traditional medicine systems in some or the other way. India has a distinctive and unique traditional medicine base, with each system having its own ancient philosophy, medicinal knowledge, perception and practices that align with the regional cultures, traditions and beliefs. The traditional medicine systems in India include Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy,Unani, Siddha, SowaRigpaand Homeopathy which is known as AYUSH. All thesesystems were formulated, practiced and perfected in a continuum much before the advent of modern health science.In many countries of the world, medical pluralism is the norm and traditional medicine is one of the surest means to achieve total healthcare coverage for the world population using acceptable, safe and economically-feasible methods. No system of medicine can single-handedly address all health concerns, but an integrative approach incorporating the positives of each can surely benefit mankind. The holistic patient-centeredand individualised approach is the trademark of traditional systems and enables the patient-physician partnership to design or customise treatment and lifestyle advice in order to achieve the highest potential for well-being. This awareness combined with the increase in use of traditional medicine has brought the systems to the fore. The diverse activities ranging from the provision of prophylactic care to the management of disease and the effective implementation and integration of AYUSHsystem to the public healthcare during the pandemic has garnered global attention to AYUSHsystems. This has enabled the signing of the Host Country Agreement for the establishment of Global Centre for Traditional Medicine (GCTM) at Jamnagar.Choose the appropriate titlefor the passage:
  • A.Allopathy
  • B.Holistic Healthcare
  • C.Ayurveda
  • D.Homeopathy
Correct Answer: Holistic Healthcare

The correct answer is option (B) - Holistic Healthcare.

 

The passage discusses various traditional medicine systems in India, such as Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy, and Homeopathy, and emphasizes a holistic, patient-centered, and individualized approach to healthcare. The passage highlights the integration of traditional medicine systems to achieve comprehensive healthcare coverage. The term "Holistic Healthcare" best captures the theme of the paragraph, which focuses on integrative and personalized healthcare approaches through traditional systems.

Quiz Attempt #119726

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow (1-5):The following table - I shows the percentage (%) distribution of patients of various diseases in the world and table -II shows the percentage (%) distribution of all the patients and Kidney patients in various continents, namely, Europe, Australia, South America, Africa, North America and Asia in the year 2023. Total population of the world in the year 2023 is 800 croresand 10% of them are patients. Based on the data in the tables, answer the questions that follow:Table I: Disease-wise Percentage of Patients in the World.Heart DiseaseAIDSTBHepatitisKidney DiseaseOthers22%10%8%6%30%24%ContinentPercentage Distribution ofAll PatientsKidney PatientsEurope10%10%Australia6%5%South America15%40%Africa25%10%North America12%15%Asia32%20%If the number of patients increases by 10% every year in Europe, then what is the difference between the number of patients in Europe after two years and the number of Kidney patients in South America in 2023?
  • A.8 lakh
  • B.9 lakh
  • C.7 lakh
  • D.5 lakh
Correct Answer: 8 lakh

Total Patients in world in 2023 = 10% of 800 = 80 crores

Patients in Europe in 2023 = 10% of 80 = 8 crores

Number of patients in Europe after 2 years = 8(1.1)2 = 9.68

Kidney patients in world in 2023 = 30% of 80 = 24 crores

Number of Kidney patients in South America in 2023 = 40% of 24 = 9.6 crores

Difference = 9.68 – 9.6 = 0.08 crore = 8 lakhs.

Question 2
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow (1-5):The following table - I shows the percentage (%) distribution of patients of various diseases in the world and table -II shows the percentage (%) distribution of all the patients and Kidney patients in various continents, namely, Europe, Australia, South America, Africa, North America and Asia in the year 2023. Total population of the world in the year 2023 is 800 crore and 10% of them are patients. Based on the data in the tables, answer the questions that follow:Table I: Disease-wise Percentage of Patients in the World.Heart DiseaseAIDSTBHepatitisKidney DiseaseOthers22%10%8%6%30%24%ContinentPercentage Distribution ofAll PatientsKidney PatientsEurope10%10%Australia6%5%South America15%40%Africa25%10%North America12%15%Asia32%20%If the number of hepatitis patients in the world increases by 6% and that of heart disease increases by 22%, then what will be the new ratio of number of hepatitis patients to the number of heartdisease patients in the world?
  • A.156:673
  • B.14:61
  • C.159:671
  • D.2:11
Correct Answer: 159:671

Total Patients in world in 2023 = 10% of 800 = 80 crores

Hapetitis patients = 6% of 80 = 4.8 crore

Heart Disease patients = 22% of 80 = 17.6 crore

New Hapetitis patients = 4.8 (1.06) = 5.088

New Heart Disease patients = 17.6 (1.22) = 21.472

Ratio = 5.08821.472 = 508821472 = 159:671

Question 3
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow (1-5):The following table - I shows the percentage (%) distribution of patients of various diseases in the world and table -II shows the percentage (%) distribution of all the patients and Kidney patients in various continents, namely, Europe, Australia, South America, Africa, North America and Asia in the year 2023. Total population of the world in the year 2023 is 800 crore and 10% of them are patients. Based on the data in the tables, answer the questions that follow:Table I: Disease-wise Percentage of Patients in the World.Heart DiseaseAIDSTBHepatitisKidney DiseaseOthers22%10%8%6%30%24%ContinentPercentage Distribution ofAll PatientsKidney PatientsEurope10%10%Australia6%5%South America15%40%Africa25%10%North America12%15%Asia32%20%If the number of Kidney patients in South America decreases by 25%, then what is the percentage decrease in the number of Kidney patients in the world?
  • A.4%
  • B.8%
  • C.10%
  • D.5%
Correct Answer: 10%

Total Patients in world in 2023 = 10% of 800 = 80 crores

Total Kidney Patients = 30% of 80 = 24 crores

Number of Kidney patients in South America = 40% of 24 = 9.6 crores

Decrease in kidney patients = 9.6 (0.25) = 2.4 crores

Percentage decrease in the number of Kidney patients in the world = 2.424 × 100 = 10%

Question 4
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow (1-5):The following table - I shows the percentage (%) distribution of patients of various diseases in the world and table -II shows the percentage (%) distribution of all the patients and Kidney patients in various continents, namely, Europe, Australia, South America, Africa, North America and Asia in the year 2023. Total population of the world in the year 2023 is 800 crore and 10% of them are patients. Based on the data in the tables, answer the questions that follow:Table I: Disease-wise Percentage of Patients in the World.Heart DiseaseAIDSTBHepatitisKidney DiseaseOthers22%10%8%6%30%24%ContinentPercentage Distribution ofAll PatientsKidney PatientsEurope10%10%Australia6%5%South America15%40%Africa25%10%North America12%15%Asia32%20%What is the ratio of the number of patients in Africa to the total number of Kidney patients in Asia and North America together
  • A.3:1
  • B.2:1
  • C.49:22
  • D.50:21
Correct Answer: 50:21

Total Patients in world in 2023 = 10% of 800 = 80 crores

Total Kidney Patients = 30% of 80 = 24 crores

Total number of Kidney patients in Asia and North America together = 35% of 24 = 8.4 crore

Required ratio = 25% of 808.4 = 20 : 8.4 = 50: 21

Question 5
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow (1-5):The following table - I shows the percentage (%) distribution of patients of various diseases in the world and table -II shows the percentage (%) distribution of all the patients and Kidney patients in various continents, namely, Europe, Australia, South America, Africa, North America and Asia in the year 2023. Total population of the world in the year 2023 is 800 croresand 10% of them are patients. Based on the data in the tables, answer the questions that follow:Table I: Disease-wise Percentage of Patients in the World.Heart DiseaseAIDSTBHepatitisKidney DiseaseOthers22%10%8%6%30%24%ContinentPercentage Distribution ofAll PatientsKidney PatientsEurope10%10%Australia6%5%South America15%40%Africa25%10%North America12%15%Asia32%20%The number of Kidney patients in Australia is approximately %of heart disease in the world.
  • A.6.01%
  • B.6.82%
  • C.5.49%
  • D.7.85%
Correct Answer: 6.82%

Total Patients in world in 2023 = 10% of 800 = 80 crores

Total Kidney Patients = 30% of 80 = 24 crores

Required percentage = 5% of 2422% of 80  × 100 = 6.82%

Question 6
Arrange the followingfractions in increasing order:A.1417B.1113C.79D.1619Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, A, B, D
  • B.C, A, D, B
  • C.A, D, C, B
  • D.B, C, A, D
Correct Answer: C, A, D, B

A. 1417 = 0.82

B. 1113 = 0.85

C. 79 = 0.78

D. 1619 = 0.84

So, the correct order be C, A, D, B

Question 7
Which of the following statements are correct as per Classical Indian School of logic (Nyaya)?A. Nyaya syllogism has three propositions.B. Nyaya syllogism has five propositions.C. Nyaya syllogism has three terms.D.Nyaya syllogism has five terms.Choose the correct answerfrom the options given below:
  • A.B and D only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A and D only
  • D.A and C only
Correct Answer: B and C only

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The Nyaya syllogism has 5 and also the Aristotelian has 3 propositions. However, the terms in both are only 3 - the sädhya or the major, the paksa or the minor and the hetu or the middle.

Question 8
If (L) represents a number L in base – M number system, then identify the correct ascending order of the following numbers A-D, when converted to a base-10 number system.A. (88)₁₆B. (212)₈C. (260)₇D. (10001101)2Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, A, C, D
  • B.D, C, A, B
  • C.A, B, C, D
  • D.C, D, B, A
Correct Answer: B, A, C, D

(8B)₁₆ = 139

(212)₈ = 138

(260)₇ = 260

(10001101)2 = 141

So, the correct order will be B, A, D, C

Question 9
Which of thefollowing statements are true?A. Truth and falsehood are attributes of individual propositions.B. Validity can never apply to any single proposition by itself.C. In a valid argument, all of its premises have to be true.D. A valid deductive argument cannot have all true premises and a false conclusion.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D only
  • B.A and C only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.C and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and D only

Statement C is incorrect because a valid argument can have one or more false premises.

Question 10
A 500 m long train running at a speed of 100 m/s crosses a tunnel in 10 s. What is the length of the tunnel?
  • A.200 m
  • B.500 m
  • C.800 m
  • D.1000 m
Correct Answer: 500 m

Let length of tunnel be x m

Then, 500+x100 = 10

or x = 500

Question 11
Which of the following is an ancient Indian treatise on problems related to Mathematics?
  • A.Nyaya Sutras
  • B.Lilavati
  • C.Mimamsa Sutras
  • D.Pramānavarttika
Correct Answer: Lilavati

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Lilavati was written by the famous astronomer and mathematician Bhaskaracharya (Bhaskara II), who was born in 1114 AD. Composed in 1150, it is the first volume of his major work, Siddhanta Shiromani ("Crown of Treatises"), which also includes Bijaganita, Grahaganita, and Goladhyaya. Lilavati provides an extensive exploration of arithmetic, algebra, geometry, mensuration, number theory, and related mathematical subjects.

Question 12
A culture which is not touched by communication of alphabetic writing isknown as a culture of:
  • A.Literacy
  • B.Typography
  • C.Exclusivity
  • D.Primary Orality
Correct Answer: Primary Orality

The correct answer is (D) Primary Orality.

 

A culture of primary orality refers to societies that rely solely on oral traditions and have not been influenced by written forms of communication, such as alphabetic writing. In such cultures, knowledge, stories, and social practices are passed down verbally from generation to generation, without the use of written language. This concept contrasts with literacy (A), which involves reading and writing, and other terms that refer to cultures that have been affected by written communication.

Question 13
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (College)A. Poona College for Hindu LearningB. Hindu College, Kolkata (Presidency College)C. Bishop College,SibpurD. Scottish Missionary College, KolkataList – II (Founder)I. Alexander DuffII. Rajaram Mohan RoyIII. Church of EnglandIV. M. ElphinstoneChoose the correctanswer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-IV, B-II, C-III, D-I
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-II, C-III, D-I

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The correct match is given below.

 

A. Poona College for Hindu Learning – IV. M. Elphinstone (established by Commissioner of Deccan-Mountstuart Elphinstone)

B. Hindu College, Kolkata (Presidency College) – II. Rajaram Mohan Roy (established in 1817, renamed as Presidency College in 1855)

C. Bishop College, Sibpur – III. Church of England (established in 1820)

D. Scottish Missionary College, Kolkata – I. Alexander Duff (established in 1830)

Question 14
What is the correct sequence (from lower number to higher) of the following related to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?A. Number ofPublicationsB. Number of GoalsC. Number of TargetsD. Number of IndicatorsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.B, D, C, A
  • C.B, C, D, A
  • D.C, B, A, D
Correct Answer: B, C, D, A

Option C is the correct answer. The correct sequence from lower to higher is given below.

 

Goals: 17 - B

Targets: 169 – C

Indicators – 247 – D

Publications: 1,351 – A

 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are a set of 17 global goals adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 as part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. These goals aim to address global challenges such as poverty, inequality, climate change, environmental degradation, peace, and justice. The SDGs are universal and interlinked, meaning that achieving one goal can contribute to the progress of others.

Question 15
Which of the following are the National Coordinators appointed for SWAYAM courses?A. Indian Institute of Management,Bangalore (IIMBB. National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning (NPTEL)C. National Institute of Open Schooling (NIOS)D. Block Institute of Teacher Education (BITE)E. Consortium forEducational Communication (CEC)Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.B and D only
  • B.C, D and E only
  • C.A, B and C only
  • D.A, B, C and E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and E only

Option D is the correct answer.

 

SWAYAM (Study Webs of Active-Learning for Young Aspiring Minds) is an initiative introduced by the Ministry of Education. It's an online platform that offers free online courses and learning materials. The courses on SWAYAM cover a wide range of subjects and levels, including school-level courses (from class 9), undergraduate and postgraduate courses, and various skill development programs.

 

National Coordinators are the Institutions that have been so designated by the Ministry and assigned a specific sector or preparation of online courses for SWAYAM. The list of 9 National Coordinators is:

(i) ICTE (All India Council for Technical Education) for self-paced and international courses

(ii) NPTEL (National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning) for Engineering

(iii) UGC (University Grants Commission) for non technical post-graduation education

(iv) CEC (Consortium for Educational Communication) for under-graduate education

(v) NCERT (National Council of Educational Research and Training) for school education

(vi) NIOS (National Institute of Open Schooling) for school education

(vii) IGNOU (Indira Gandhi National Open University) for out-of-school students

(viii) IIMB (Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore) for management studies

(ix) NITTTR (National Institute of Technical Teachers Training and Research) for Teacher Training programme.

Question 16
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Internet Protocol)A. HTTPB. SSLC. SMTPD. FTPList – II (Internet Activity)I. Sends email through the InternetII. Encryptsdata for online transmissionIII. Sends TCP/IP packets to web serverIV. Transfers files over the InternetChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-I, B-IV, C-III, D-II
  • D.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
Question 17
Which of the following statements is logically equivalent to the statement “No cats are non-feline.”?
  • A.No felines are cats.
  • B.All non-cats are feline.
  • C.All cats are feline.
  • D.All felines are cats
Correct Answer: All cats are feline.

Option C is the correct answer. It is logically equivalent to the given statement “No cats are non-feline.”

Question 18
The systematic elimination of extraneous variables other than those you are interested in can be achieved in:
  • A.qualitative research
  • B.correlational research
  • C.experimental research
  • D.longitudinal research
Correct Answer: experimental research

The correct answer is (C) Experimental research.

 

In experimental research, researchers systematically control and manipulate variables to isolate the effect of the independent variable while eliminating or minimizing the influence of extraneous variables, ensuring more accurate cause-and-effect conclusions. This level of control is unique to experimental designs.

Question 19
Identify the correct sequence of the cycle of self-regulated learning.A.Enacting Tactics and strategiesB. Devising PlansC. Setting GoalsD. Regulating learningE. Analyzing the taskChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, B, C, A, E
  • B.C, D, B, A, E
  • C.E, C, B, A, D
  • D.A, B, C, D, E
Correct Answer: E, C, B, A, D

The correct answer is (C) E, C, B, A, D.

 

In self-regulated learning, the correct sequence begins with analyzing the task (E), followed by setting goals (C), then devising plans (B) to achieve those goals. Next, the learner engages in enacting tactics and strategies (A), and finally, regulates learning (D) by adjusting their approach as needed.

Question 20
Around 1945, who developed the idea of a stored program computer that was to hold programs and data in a memory and then data would move between the memory and the processor?
  • A.Alan Turing
  • B.Tim Berners-Lee
  • C.Charles Babbage
  • D.John Von Neumann
Correct Answer: John Von Neumann

The correct answer is (D) John Von Neumann.

 

John Von Neumann developed the concept of the stored-program computer around 1945. His architecture proposed that both the program instructions and the data could be stored in the same memory, allowing the CPU to fetch instructions and data dynamically as needed. This architecture, known as the Von Neumann architecture, is fundamental to most computer systems today.

Question 21
Which of the following statements about computer memories is correct?
  • A.HDDs may experience a “head crash”.
  • B.SSDs are also known as volatile memory.
  • C.HDDs do not have any moving parts.
  • D.Computers usually have more primary memory than secondary memory
Correct Answer: HDDs may experience a “head crash”.

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is (A) HDDs may experience a “head crash.” This statement is correct. A head crash occurs when the read/write head of a hard disk drive (HDD) comes into contact with the spinning platters, which can cause data loss and damage to the drive.

Question 22
Which digital platform of Ministry of Education has been formed by merging three consortia initiatives, namely UGC-INFONET Digital library consortium, NLIST and INDEST-AICTE consortium?
  • A.ShodhGanga
  • B.e-ShodhSindhu
  • C.E-Vidwan
  • D.ShodhShuddhi
Correct Answer: e-ShodhSindhu

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Based on the recommendation of an Expert Committee, the Ministry of Education has formed e-ShodhSindhu merging three consortia initiatives, namely UGC-INFONET Digital Library Consortium, NLIST and INDEST-AICTE Consortium. The e-ShodhSindhu aims to provide current as well as archival access to more than 10,000 core and peer-reviewed journals and a number of bibliographic, citation and factual databases in different disciplines from a large number of publishers and aggregators to its member institutions including centrally-funded technical institutions.

Question 23
Match List – I with List – II.List-I (Communication form)A. Personal addressB. Social dramaC. NarrativesD. SilenceList – II (Description)I. Sequential accounts told and retold from a particular viewpointII. Subject to a community’s rules for appropriate conductIII. Points toself and others in interactionIV. Invokes local socio-cultural rules for behaviorChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-III, D-IV
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II

The correct answer is (C) A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II.

 

A. Personal address (III): Refers to how individuals point to themselves and others in interactions.

B. Social drama (IV): Involves invoking local socio-cultural rules for behavior.

C. Narratives (I): Are sequential accounts told and retold from a particular viewpoint.

D. Silence (II): Reflects adherence to a community's rules for appropriate conduct.

Question 24
Which of the following computer devices are output devices only?A. Track ballB. CRT monitorC. Number padD. PlotterChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.A, B and D only
  • C.C and D only
  • D.B and D only
Correct Answer: B and D only

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is (D) B and D only.

 

CRT Monitor (B): This is an output device that displays visual output from the computer. It shows images, text, and videos on the screen.

 

Plotter (D): This is also an output device that produces hard copy graphics. It is used for printing high-quality images, such as engineering drawings or CAD designs.

Question 25
Which of the following are true about Solar Thermal Energy Collectors (STEC)?A. Basic unit of STEC is a solar cell.B. STECs may be flat plate or concentrating type.C. Temperature in STECs may rise over a thousand degrees Celsius.D.STECs can produce electricity.E. Paraboloid dish collector is an example of STEC where temperature can go up to 2000°C.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and D only
  • B.B, C, D and E only
  • C.A, B, C and E only
  • D.A, B, C, D and E
Correct Answer: B, C, D and E only

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Only Statement 1 false. The basic unit of a Solar Thermal Energy Collector (STEC) is not a solar cell. Solar cells are used in photovoltaic systems, not in solar thermal energy collectors. STECs work by collecting and concentrating solar energy as heat, rather than directly converting it into electricity as solar cells do.

 

Solar Thermal Energy Collectors (STEC) are devices that capture and convert solar energy into heat. This heat can then be used for various applications, such as heating water or air, generating electricity, or even powering industrial processes. STECs do not convert sunlight directly into electricity like photovoltaic (PV) cells; instead, they absorb the sun's rays and convert them into thermal energy (heat).

Question 26
Arrange the following sections of a research dissertation in correct sequence:A. AcknowledgementB. Research MethodsC. DiscussionD. Literature ReviewChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.B, D, C, A
  • C.D, B, C, A
  • D.A, D, B, C
Correct Answer: A, D, B, C

The correct answer is (D) A, D, B, C.

 

A research dissertation typically begins with the Acknowledgment (A) section to thank contributors. This is followed by the Literature Review (D), where previous research is discussed. Next, the Research Methods (B) section outlines the methodology used in the study. Finally, the Discussion (C) section interprets the results and connects them to the research questions and literature review.

Question 27
“I believe I will do well in this class,” Ram declared to his brother. “I received a perfect score on the verbal part of the SAT, and I have always excelled in my literature classes.” Ram is demonstrating which of the following?
  • A.High self-esteem
  • B.High levels of empathy
  • C.High self-efficacy in literature
  • D.Low self-efficacy in literature
Correct Answer: High self-efficacy in literature

The correct answer is (C) High self-efficacy in literature.

 

Self-efficacy refers to an individual's belief in their ability to succeed in specific tasks or situations. In this case, Ram is expressing confidence in his ability to do well in his literature class, based on his past successes, such as scoring well on the verbal part of the SAT and excelling in previous literature courses.

Question 28
A sum of ₹50 is divided among A, B, and C in such a way that A gets ₹5 less than B, and B gets ₹10 less than C. What isthe ratio of their money share?
  • A.1:2:3
  • B.2:3:4
  • C.1:2:4
  • D.2:3:5
Correct Answer: 2:3:5

Let C gets Rs. x, then B gets x-10 and A will get x-15

According to the statement

x – 15 + x – 10 + x = 50

or 3 x = 75

or x = 25

Ratio = 10 : 15 : 25 = 2 : 3 : 5

Question 29
Identify the correct sequence (from earliest to latest) of the universities established in the early years of the20thcentury India:A. Osmania UniversityB. Aligarh Muslim UniversityC. SNDT Women’s UniversityD. Nagpur UniversityE. Patna UniversityChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, A, C, B, D
  • B.C, E, A, B, D
  • C.D, A, C, E, B
  • D.A, D, E, B, C
Correct Answer: C, E, A, B, D

Option B is the correct answer.

 

SNDT Women’s University – The University was founded by Maharshi Dr. Dhondo Keshav Karve in 1916 for a noble cause of Women’s Education. – C

Patna University was established in the year 1917 – E

Osmania University – established in 1917 – A

Aligarh Muslim University – On 7 January 1877, Sir Syed founded the Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College in Aligarh. By 1920 the college was transformed into the Aligarh Muslim University – B

Nagpur University was established in 1923 – D

Question 30
Identify the list of 4 quadrantsof the courses hosted on SWAYAM –A. Self-assessment testsB. Video lectureC. Online discussion forum for clearing the doubtsD. Specially prepared reading materialthat can be downloaded/printedE. Face-to-Face interaction among learnersChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, D, and E only
  • B.A, B, C, and D only
  • C.C, D, and E only
  • D.C and E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C, and D only

Option B is the correct answer.

 

SWAYAM (Study Webs of Active-Learning for Young Aspiring Minds) is an initiative introduced by the Ministry of Education. It's an online platform that offers free online courses and learning materials. The courses on SWAYAM cover a wide range of subjects and levels, including school-level courses (from class 9), undergraduate and postgraduate courses, and various skill development programs.

 

The courses being offered on SWAYAM have following the four-quadrant instructional design:

Quadrant-I is e-Tutorial, which shall contain Video and Audio Content in an organised form, Animation, Simulations, video demonstrations, Virtual Labs, etc.

Quadrant-II is e-Content, which shall contain PDF, Text, e-Books, illustrations, video demonstrations, documents and Interactive simulations wherever required.

Quadrant-III is Web Resources, which shall contain Related Links, Wikipedia Development of Course, Open source Content on Internet, Case Studies, books including e-books, research papers & journals, Anecdotal information, Historical development of the subject, Articles, etc.

Quadrant-IV is Self-Assessment, which shall contain Problems and Solutions, which could be in the form of Multiple Choice Questions, Fill in the blanks, Matching Questions, Short Answer Questions, Long Answer Questions, Quizzes, Assignments and solutions, Discussion forum topics and setting up the FAQs, Clarifications on general misconceptions.

Question 31
Arrange the following in order of increasing connotation:A. Domestic AnimalB. AnimalC. HorseD. Beast of burdenChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, D, B, A
  • B.B, A, C, D
  • C.B, A, D, C
  • D.C, D, A, B
Correct Answer: B, A, D, C

The correct answer is (C) because "Animal" (B) is the broadest and least specific term, followed by "Domestic Animal" (A), which refers to animals living with humans. "Beast of burden" (D) adds more specific associations of labor, and "Horse" (C) is the most specific and culturally connotative term.

Question 32
In Buddhist thought, self-reflexivity is built into the process of:
  • A.Power relations
  • B.Religious change
  • C.Verbal communication
  • D.Politicization
Correct Answer: Verbal communication

Option C is the correct answer.

 

In Buddhism, language and communication are seen as pathways to ultimate liberation. As a result, self-reflexivity and critical introspection—the essence of intrapersonal communication—are given great significance.

 

For Buddhists, this self-reflexivity is deeply embedded in the process of verbal communication. When communicating, one is not merely stringing together words but also reflecting on and evaluating them. To communicate and use language to connect with others is to adopt a moral stance. This leads to the idea that linguistic communication involves not only the sharing of information but also the expression of emotions and moral judgments. Therefore, communicating through language involves reflecting on one's identity as a human being. This important aspect has been largely overlooked by communication scholars.

Question 33
Which ofthe following statements are true regarding Macaulay?A. He succeeded in replacing Persian with English as the administrative language.B. He promoted training of English-speaking Indians as teachers.C. He wasinspired by Utilitarian ideas.D.He promoted “useful learning”.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A and C only
  • D.A, B, C, and D
Correct Answer: A, B, C, and D

All the statements are correct.

 

Statement A is correct. Thomas Babington Macaulay played a key role in the introduction of English as the official language in India, replacing Persian. His famous 1835 "Minute on Indian Education" emphasized the use of English for education and administration.

 

Statement B is correct. Macaulay believed in educating a class of English-speaking Indians who could serve as intermediaries between the British and the local population. This group was trained to be teachers and civil servants who would help implement British policies.

 

Statement C is correct. Macaulay was influenced by Utilitarian philosophy, which focuses on the greatest good for the greatest number. He believed that introducing English education and Western knowledge would lead to progress and development in India.

 

Statement D is correct. Macaulay was influenced by Utilitarian philosophy, which focuses on the greatest good for the greatest number. He believed that introducing English education and Western knowledge would lead to progress and development in India.

Question 34
The Gross Enrolment Ratio (GER) measures the number of students enrolled in higher education as a percentage of the eligible population aged between:
  • A.18 to 24 years
  • B.19 to 25 years
  • C.18 to 23 years
  • D.17 to 23 years
Correct Answer: 18 to 23 years

The Gross Enrolment Ratio (GER) in higher education measures the total enrollment of students in higher education institutions as a percentage of the population in the eligible age group. The age group considered for GER in higher education is 18 to 23 years. This ratio helps gauge the accessibility of higher education for individuals in that specific age range.

Question 35
Which one of the following is an extremely short-lived and unstable air/water pollutant?
  • A.SMOG
  • B.Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)
  • C.Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs)
  • D.Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs)
Correct Answer: Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)

Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) are a group of organic chemicals that have a high vapor pressure at room temperature, making them volatile. They are released into the air from various sources, such as paints, solvents, and fuels. VOCs are considered extremely short-lived and unstable in the atmosphere because they can quickly evaporate and react with other pollutants, leading to the formation of secondary pollutants like ground-level ozone.

Question 36
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Threats to Internal Validity)A. Maturation threatB. Attrition threatC. History threatD. Testing threatList – II (Description)I. When participants’ behavior changes as a function of having been tested previouslyII. When some event outside the research project affects participants systematicallyIII. Occurs because of short- or long-term changes in a participant because of psychological changes like boredom, fatigue etc.IV. When participants drop out of a study, leading to a change in the nature of the sampleChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
  • B.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • C.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • D.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I

The correct answer is (B) A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I.

 

A. Maturation threat (III): Refers to changes in participants over time due to psychological factors like fatigue or boredom.

B. Attrition threat (IV): Occurs when participants drop out, altering the sample.

C. History threat (II): Happens when external events affect participants systematically.

D. Testing threat (I): Arises when previous testing influences participants' behavior in subsequent tests.

Question 37
Match List I with List – II.List – I (Words)A. BOLTB. RINGC. SOLDD. FROMList – II (Codes with same rule)I. 52II. 50III. 49IV. 48Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The question involves assigning a numerical code to each word based on a specific rule, such as the sum of the positions of the letters in the alphabet (A = 1, B = 2, C = 3, etc.).

 

The correct match is given below.

A (BOLT) = 49 → IV

B (RING) = 48 → III

C (SOLD) = 50 → I

D (FROM) = 52 → II

Question 38
International Solar Alliance (ISA) is the alliance of countries most of which lie partially or completely:
  • A.Above tropic of cancer
  • B.Below tropic of Capricorn
  • C.Between tropic of cancer and tropic of Capricorn
  • D.Southern hemisphere
Correct Answer: Between tropic of cancer and tropic of Capricorn

The International Solar Alliance (ISA) is an international organization launched to promote solar energy use among countries that receive abundant sunlight, particularly those located between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn, which includes the tropical region. This region has the highest potential for solar energy due to year-round solar exposure.

Question 39
Identify the scale/scales of measurement which would align ranking of observations.A. nominal scaleB. ordinal scaleC. interval scaleD. ratio scaleChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.B only
  • D.A and B only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

The ordinal scale (B) is designed for ranking observations based on their order. The interval scale (C) and ratio scale (D) also allow ranking because they measure differences between observations, with the ratio scale having a true zero. The nominal scale (A), however, only categorizes data without ranking.

Question 40
Match List – I with List – II.List – I (Water specific diseases)A. Water borne diseasesB. Water washed diseasesC. Water based diseasesD. Water related diseasesList – II (Examples)I. MalariaII. SchistosomiasisIII. TyphoidIV. TrachomaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • B.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • C.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • D.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Water-borne diseases: diseases spread through water in which water acts as a passive carrier for the infecting pathogens. These diseases depend also on sanitation. Some of the examples include - Cholera, Typhoid, Bacillary dysentry, Infectious hepatitis, Leptospirosis, Giardiasis, Gastroenteriris etc.

 

Water-related diseases: diseases spread by vectors and insects that live in or close to water. Stagnant ponds of water provides the breeding place for the disease spreading vectors such as mosquitoes, flies and insects. Some of the examples include - Yellow fever, Dengue fever, Encephalitis, Malaria, Filariasis (all by mosquitoes), Sleeping sickness (Tsetse fly), Onchocerciasis (Simulium fly) etc.

 

Water-based diseases: diseases caused by infecting agents spread by contact with or ingestion of water. Water supports an essential part of the life cycle of infecting agents such as aquatic snails. Some of the examples include - Schistosomiasis, Dracunculosis, Bilharziosis, Philariosis, Oncholersosis, Treadworm and other helminths.

 

Water-washed diseases: diseases caused by the lack of adequate quantity of water for proper maintenance of personal hygiene. Some are also depended on poor sanitation. Some of the examples includes - Scabies, Trachoma (eye-infection), Leprosy, Conjuctivitis, Salmonellosis, Ascariasis, Trichuriasis, Hookworm, Amoebic dysentery, Paratyphoid fever etc.

Question 41
Which of the following refers to a sampling approach in structured observation whereby a sampled individual is observed for a set period of time?
  • A.Focal sampling
  • B.Snowball sampling
  • C.Purposive sampling
  • D.Cluster sampling
Correct Answer: Focal sampling

The correct answer is (A) Focal sampling.

 

Focal sampling is a structured observation method where a specific individual is observed for a predetermined period. This approach allows researchers to gather detailed information about that individual’s behaviour during the observation time, making it distinct from other sampling methods like snowball, purposive, or cluster sampling, which have different objectives and methodologies.

Question 42
Employment of classroom technology needs clarity with regard to:A. Instructional messagesB.Course objectivesC. Technological competenciesD. Experience of failuresE. Institutional indolenceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

The correct answer is (A) A, B and C only.

 

When employing classroom technology, it is essential to clarify instructional messages (A) to ensure effective communication, course objectives (B) to align technology use with learning goals, and technological competencies (C) to ensure both educators and students can effectively utilize the technology.

Question 43
Which of the following are the characteristics of mass communication?A. Homogeneous audienceB. Professional communication as sourceC. Immediate feedbackD. Use of a mediumE. Rapid transmission of messagesChoose the most appropriate answer from the optionsgiven below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.B, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, D and E only

The correct answer is (D) B, D and E only.

 

Characteristics of mass communication include professional communication as a source (B), where messages are crafted by skilled communicators; use of a medium (D), as mass communication relies on various platforms like television, radio, and the internet to disseminate information; and rapid transmission of messages (E), which highlights the ability to quickly spread information to large audiences. A homogeneous audience and immediate feedback are not defining traits of mass communication; rather, audiences can be diverse, and feedback is often delayed.

Question 44
Which fallacy is committed in the following statement:“Tarun cannot be guilty of murder since there is noway Tarun could kill someone.”
  • A.Hasty Generalization
  • B.Slippery Slope
  • C.Begging the Question
  • D.Inappropriate Authority
Correct Answer: Begging the Question

The correct answer is (C) Begging the Question.

 

The statement commits the fallacy of begging the question because it assumes Tarun's innocence without providing evidence, essentially stating that he cannot be guilty because he is incapable of committing the act. This reasoning is circular, as it relies on the conclusion (his innocence) to support itself without addressing the actual question of his guilt or innocence in the murder.

Question 45
Which of the following statements are correct?A. A man purchased an item at 4/5​ of its selling price ‘X’, and sold it at 5% more than ‘X’. His gain is 25%.B. A dealer professes to sell his goods at cost price but uses a weight of 900g for a kg weight. His gain is 1119%.C. If loss is one third of the selling price, the loss percentage is 25%.D. By selling 100 pens, a vendor gains the selling price of 20 pens. His gain is 20%.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.C and D only
  • D.A and D only
Correct Answer: B and C only

A. CP = 45 x = 0.8x

SP = 1.05x

Profit = 1.05 – 0.8 = 0.25x

Profit percent = 0.25x0.8x × 100 = 312.5%

 

B. CP for product = 900x

SP = 1000 x

Profit % = 1000x-900x900x × 100

= 11 19 %

 

C. Let SP = x

Loss = x3

CP = x + x3 = 4x3

Loss % = x34x3 × 100 = 25%

 

D. CP = 80x

SP = 100x

Gain = 100x – 80x = 20x

Gain % = 20x80x × 100 = 25%

Thus, only B and C are true.

Question 46
Read the question and answer the following question.Micron’s $800 million semiconductor plant followed by recent approval to Tata Group and CG Power for fabrication and Assembly, Testing and Packaging (ATP) plants with an investment of Rs 1,30,000 crore (and more in the pipeline) are the beginning of a transformational global supply chain shift centered around chip manufacturing in India. This will create a multiplier effect on talented and skilled workforce inside India.It’s a matter of pride that almost one-third of the global semiconductor talent pool is Indian. However, the need for domestic semiconductor workforce is estimated to be around 3,00,000 by 2026. In addition, there is also a huge manpower requirement of almost six million in the electronics manufacturing sector which will be the largest beneficiary of the chip boom.The current combined Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) graduate output from India’s higher education institutions is inadequate.The growth is certainly going to come from the non-IITiansorbit and the policy path ways of the Ministries of Electronics and IT and Education converge to present bountiful opportunities for industry and academia to work together.This industry academia synergy was key to India’s software success story. Now a similar trifecta of government-industry-academia is needed to make this a winningsemicontrio.As a result of the chip boom, the requirement of workforce in the electronics manufacturing sector will:
  • A.Remain Unchanged
  • B.Lead to Job Losses
  • C.Increase
  • D.Drastically go down
Correct Answer: Increase

As mentioned in the passage,

 

The chip boom in India, driven by large investments in semiconductor plants, will significantly boost demand for skilled workers in the electronics manufacturing sector, increasing workforce requirements to meet the industry's growing needs. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Increase.

Question 47
Read the question and answer the following question.Micron’s $800 million semiconductor plant followed by recent approval to Tata Group and CG Power for fabrication and Assembly, Testing and Packaging (ATP) plants with an investment of Rs 1,30,000 crore (and more in the pipeline) are the beginning of a transformational global supply chain shift centered around chip manufacturing in India. This will create a multiplier effect on talented and skilled workforce inside India.It’s a matter of pride that almost one-third of the global semiconductor talent pool is Indian. However, the need for domestic semiconductor workforce is estimated to be around 3,00,000 by 2026. In addition, there is also a huge manpower requirement of almost six million in the electronics manufacturing sector which will be the largest beneficiary of the chip boom.The current combined Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) graduate output from India’s higher education institutions is inadequate.The growth is certainly going to come from the non-IITiansorbit and the policy path ways of the Ministries of Electronics and IT and Education converge to present bountiful opportunities for industry and academia to work together.This industry academia synergy was key to India’s software success story. Now a similar trifecta of government-industry-academia is needed to make this a winningsemicontrio.The new talented skills workforce in India will come mainly from:
  • A.STEM Graduates
  • B.The Non-IITiansorbit
  • C.The IIT’s
  • D.UnskilledLabourForce
Correct Answer: The Non-IITiansorbit

The correct answer is (B) The Non-IITians orbit.

 

The passage mentions that the growth of the semiconductor workforce will primarily come from the non-IITians orbit, as India's current STEM graduate output is inadequate, and the semiconductor industry will require collaboration between government, industry, and academia to fill the talent gap.

Question 48
Read the question and answer the following question.Micron’s $800 million semiconductor plant followed by recent approval to Tata Group and CG Power for fabrication and Assembly, Testing and Packaging (ATP) plants with an investment of Rs 1,30,000 crores(and more in the pipeline) are the beginning of a transformational global supply chain shift centered around chip manufacturing in India. This will create a multiplier effect on talented and skilled workforce inside India.It’s a matter of pride that almost one-third of the global semiconductor talent pool is Indian. However, the need for domestic semiconductor workforce is estimated to be around 3,00,000 by 2026. In addition, there is also a huge manpower requirement of almost six million in the electronics manufacturing sector which will be the largest beneficiary of the chip boom.The current combined Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) graduate output from India’s higher education institutions is inadequate.The growth is certainly going to come from the non-IITiansorbit and the policy path ways of the Ministries of Electronics and IT and Education converge to present bountiful opportunities for industry and academia to work together.This industry academia synergy was key to India’s software success story. Now a similar trifecta of government-industry-academia is needed to make this a winningsemicontrio.India’s share in the semiconductor global talent pool is:
  • A.Two-thirds
  • B.One-third
  • C.Three-fourths
  • D.One-fifth
Correct Answer: One-third

The correct answer is (B) One-third.

 

The passage highlights that almost one-third of the global semiconductor talent pool is Indian, making option B the correct answer.

Question 49
Read the question and answer the following question.Micron’s $800 million semiconductor plant followed by recent approval to Tata Group and CG Power for fabrication and Assembly, Testing and Packaging (ATP) plants with an investment of Rs 1,30,000 crores(and more in the pipeline) are the beginning of a transformational global supply chain shift centered around chip manufacturing in India. This will create a multiplier effect on talented and skilled workforce inside India.It’s a matter of pride that almost one-third of the global semiconductor talent pool is Indian. However, the need for domestic semiconductor workforce is estimated to be around 3,00,000 by 2026. In addition, there is also a huge manpower requirement of almost six million in the electronics manufacturing sector which will be the largest beneficiary of the chip boom.The current combined Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) graduate output from India’s higher education institutions is inadequate.The growth is certainly going to come from the non-IITiansorbit and the policy path ways of the Ministries of Electronics and IT and Education converge to present bountiful opportunities for industry and academia to work together.This industry academia synergy was key to India’s software success story. Now a similar trifecta of government-industry-academia is needed to make this a winningsemicontrio.Micron set up a:
  • A.Fabrication plant
  • B.An ATP plant
  • C.A semiconductor plant
  • D.An engineering college
Correct Answer: A semiconductor plant

The correct answer is (C) A semiconductor plant.

 

The passage states that Micron established an $800 million semiconductor plant in India, marking the beginning of a shift in global supply chains centered around chip manufacturing. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

Question 50
Read the question and answer the following question.Micron’s $800 million semiconductor plant followed by recent approval to Tata Group and CG Power for fabrication and Assembly, Testing and Packaging (ATP) plants with an investment of Rs 1,30,000 crores(and more in the pipeline) are the beginning of a transformational global supply chain shift centered around chip manufacturing in India. This will create a multiplier effect on talented and skilled workforce inside India.It’s a matter of pride that almost one-third of the global semiconductor talent pool is Indian. However, the need for domestic semiconductor workforce is estimated to be around 3,00,000 by 2026. In addition, there is also a huge manpower requirement of almost six million in the electronics manufacturing sector which will be the largest beneficiary of the chip boom.The current combined Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) graduate output from India’s higher education institutions is inadequate.The growth is certainly going to come from the non-IITiansorbit and the policy path ways of the Ministries of Electronics and IT and Education converge to present bountiful opportunities for industry and academia to work together.This industry academia synergy was key to India’s software success story. Now a similar trifecta of government-industry-academia is needed to make this a winningsemicontrio.The need for additional talented and skilled workforce in the domestic semiconductor sector has been created by:A. The approval given to Tata Group and CG Power for fabrication and ATP plantsB. Micron’s $800 million semiconductor plantC. Setting up of new UniversitiesD. The global supply chain shift centered around chip manufacturing in IndiaChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.A, C and D only
  • C.B, C and D only
  • D.A, B and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and D only

The correct answer is (D) A, B and D only.

 

The need for additional skilled workforce in India's semiconductor sector is driven by:

 

A: The approval given to Tata Group and CG Power for fabrication and ATP plants.

B: Micron's $800 million semiconductor plant.

D: The global supply chain shift centered around chip manufacturing in India. These factors contribute to the growing demand for talent, while setting up new universities (C) is not specifically mentioned as a direct cause in the passage.

Quiz Attempts 761-770 of 849
